tions were given—there are overdue bills in every bank, but I certainly did not know that overdue bills that were forged were included in that item—The instructions given by the directors were that all the past-due bills were to be placed at their true value, making such allowance as was believed to be correct, as to the dividends that might be returnable on; them—I held 537 shares in the Unity Bank—the total number of the shares was 3,000, and I held more than a sixth of the whole capital of the bank—I recollect the failure of the Royal British Bank, and purchasing about that time a large number of the shares of the Unity Bank—it was then that I borrowed a considerable portion of the 23,000l. from the bank to buy the shares; giving the bank at the same time ample security, independently of the shares themselves—that was done at the carnest request of the then manager, Mr. Chambers—there was a great panic at that time, and our bank was only four months old—I made all the circumstances of the loan known to the shareholders at the time—the secretary always attended the board and entered the minutes—loans and renewals of loans were brought under the attention of the directors, as were also discharges by the bank of debts due to the bank—the release to Bunyard of 5,000l. was totally unknown to us—I had no knowledge that Terry had given a release for that debt—it was never brought to the attention of the board while I was present—no entry of the 996l. transaction with Bunyard was entered on the minutes or brought to my attention—I had told Terry I did not like the appearance of Bunyard, and that he must be very careful with respect to him—he said proper inquiries had been made, and that the securities were good. I think Perl's case was brought before us, and that Terry was authorized to take a composition, Perl having failed—it was hoped Perl would pay 12s. 6d. in the pound, but those hopes were never realized—he paid 1s. in the pound—the debt was 8,000l. odd—I did not know that Terry had signed the deed of composition for 2, 500l. only—(MR. HOWELL signed for those bills he expected to be dishonoured, the others he expected to be taken up by the acceptors)—There was no concealment in Perl's case of which I am aware—I frequently spoke to Terry as to Lowenthal's account—it was constantly a subject of discussion and anxiety at the board—Mr. Burch was always present on these occasions—we often referred to the mauager

as to whether he was satisfied with the securities and the bond fides of the transactions—his replies were satisfactory—I did not know Ironsides or that he was a customer of the bank—I did not know that some of Lowenthal's bills were substitutions for the acceptances of Ironsides, or given up for those acceptances—I remember F. W. Hall being a debtor to the bank—his debt was discussed at the bank in the presence of Burch, and sometimes of Terry—Terry was called in and warned to be careful with respect to Hall—he said he had confidence in him and was satisfied, or words to that effect—we knew nothing of him ourselves—the manager was not generally present at the meetings; we sent for him when we wanted him—we sat twice a week, and in the interim we called frequently at the bank—he had access to the minutes when he chose—my instructions as to discounting bills were to prefer security before profit—there was a book called the "Cash Article Book"—it was generally read over week by week at the board meetings, but I am not quite sure it was read latterly—the secretary read it—I have no recollection of an item in the book of 1, 095l., in respect to a cheque of Sterne, drawn on Martin, being read over—I could not say how many entries were read—they ought to have been all read, if at all—the book was left on the table, four or five directors sitting round—we never looked at the book—I am quite sure Sterne's name was not called out, or it would have attracted our attention—directions were given after the 30th of June, 1862, by me or Mr. Eyre, to prepare a book containing a list of debts due to the bank—the one produced is it—it is partly in Burch's and partly in Terry's handwriting—the book begins in January, 1863, and pur
ports to show the debts, good, bad, and. indifferent, due to the bank—it was certainly not with my knowledge, or that of the directors, that the debts of Sterne, Bunyard, Lowenthal, Harris, or Jabez Wood, were omitted from that book—the object of the book was to show what was owing to the bank and what was paid—I recollect that book being produced to the directors, it was the subject of discussion, sometimes with the manager, and sometimes with the secretary—in February, 1864, I recollect going to a meeting of shareholders, and having a conversation with Burch before, going—that was on the 9th of February—I asked him what had become of our assets, our money in the Unity, adding that I could not understand why we owed the London and Middlesex money, and that there ought to be money of our own, or words to that effect—he produced a small book in which were several names of persons represented as owing us money, including Lowenthal and others—I had believed that those debts had been paid long before—I expressed my surprise, and asked why he had not mentioned that before—he replied that he did not like to do so—shortly afterwards, on the same day, I communicated the facts to the directors—Terry was spoken to on the subject during the day—he was called to account about it, but I could not state what took place so well as the other directors—I lost quite 18,000l. in the bank—that was by the depreciation of the shares; in fact every year I was losing about 3,000l. by these conceal ments.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT PARRY. Q. You were governor of the bank for two years, were you not? A. I was, and chairman—I was to have had 500l. a year as chairman if the bank had been prosperous, but I declined to take it while the bank was not making a profit—I was to be paid that for devoting more time to the affairs of the bank than the other direc-tors—Terry at one time had 500l., a year, but that was reduced to 450l. MR. Chambers, the first manager, had 800l., a year; Mr. Burch had 200l.,

and originally 160l. a year—I knew that Terry had been sixteen years in the bank of Jones Loyd and Co., and we had perfect confidence in him—I knew the item 207, 668l. contained past-due bills and cheques in suspense, but I did not know the exact amount of those bills and cheques—I have no doubt the amount was stated to us—it was 20,000l. odd, but I cannot recollect—I did not know that it amounted to nearer 50,000l. than 20,000l., but the amount, whether 50,000l. or 20,000l., was known to me and the other directors—I am one of the liquidators by virtue of my office as a director under the charter—we, as directors, do not oppose the prosecu
tion, nor do we sanction it; we do neither—there are three other directors besides myself, namely, Mr. Deputy Bower, Mr. Eyre, and Mr. Hayward, of the Minories, all four well-known gentlemen in the City of London—we have taken no part in the prosecution; we did not oppose it—the prosecution has been instituted by the direction of the Master of the Rolls—we, as directors, knew of the gross amount of past-due bills and cheques in suspense.

Q. This, you know, is a celebrated item, and will always be so in the banking world—I mean "bills discounted, loans to customers, &c. 207, 668l."—why did not the directors divide that item into three parts, so as to show what was cash, what were past-due bills, and what were cheques in suspense? A. We placed the item in that way as all other banks do, or did up to that time, latterly there has been an alteration in some—there always must be past-due bills in a bank, and a great many whose realization must always be uncertain, depending as they must do on a great many circumstances and contingencies which I think I need not illustrate—some bankrupts' estates are occasionally twenty years in being wound up—I was not aware that the forged bills were carried into the balance-sheet as good"—we knew that Ollivier's and Frasi's bills were forged—they ought to have been written off—I do not know that they were—the general instructions of the directors were to write off what was bad—I mean to say, that a manager of his own accord would be at liberty to write off debts that he thought were bad, with
out the sanction of the directors; I would call it deducting from the profits of the half-year—the instructions were to make a true and faithful account of the affairs of the bank; I frequently; have those instructions—I did not suspect that the manager was doing otherwise—every half-year I charged the defendants to make out a true and faithful balance-sheet—the expression "preferring security to profit" which I have used may be found in Gilbert's Book on Banking—that, at all events, was my rule—I did it to give confi
dence to our manager; he looked to me very much.

Q. Suppose the name of an acceptor was forged, but the drawer and endorser were good, you would not write it off would you? A. If there was a prospect of getting the money from it, certainly not—if a bank was unfortunate enough to have 10,000l. worth of forged bills, the manager could write that off; he must write it off to make up the balance-sheet—I think it would be very necessary to give some account to the shareholders if there was so large an amount as that—if there was a prospect of getting the money, you would put it at its estimated value.
COURT. Q. Is there any written authority anywhere for writing off any amount except for the 38,000l.,? A. No; I think not.

MR. SERJEANT PARRY. Q. That 38,000l. was recommended to be written off by the shareholders, was it not? A. We could not write it off capital with out their sanction—if these forged bills had been written off, I presume it would have been a past-due bills account; it would diminish the amount of the

past-due bills—it must appear in some account of the bank-books—the British Bank failed In September, 1856, when we were four months' old—I originally took twenty shares, the same as the other directors, to buy which I borrowed 1,000l., from the Unity Life-office, and afterwards repaid it—the directors never had any shares allotted to them for which they did not pay—there was a panic, and a run upon the bank in the autumn of 1856, the shareholders were destroying their own property—the average cost of my shares was 42l. 10s. a share, and I shall, I hope, get back 16l. a share—I have had to pay interest all the time, without receiving any divi
dend—I subsequently bought shares at a lower rate with the view to recoup myself, but I still lost 18,000l., notwithstanding—one duty a manager is to see the customers; a great deal of paper is passed on a new bank, much of which is very doubtful—the difficulty of a new bank is that the manager at first does not know his customers, and he makes advances, often at con
siderable loss in the end—I knew nothing of the trust-deed in Bunyard's case—I knew securities were deposited with respect to Bunyard's debt in the shape of hope and guano—I do not recollect 5,000l., of Micklam's bonds being deposited—I believe Terry was serious in his belief that 12s. 6d. in the pound would be obtained in Perl's case—Sterne's name was never called over as appearing in the cash article book—I knew him very well—my partner, Mr. Bazin, was well acquainted with him, under the same circumstances as I myself was; namely, by his coming to the bank—I have heard the name of Martin called, but not of Sterne—the cheque in question of Sterne was upon Martin—I am not aware that I ever looked into the cash article book—our meetings lasted two or three hours; I can't tell whether the book was produced the first part of the day—after being read I have no doubt it was placed on the table of the board—having had the book read to us we did not look into it, we having confidence in the manager and secretary—the book was left once a week on the table of the board—I am not aware that I heard Sterne's cheque read over more than once—the entry would not attract my attention in the name of Martin, we having no customer of that name—the name of Mr. Eyre, a director, for l, 500l., was in the cash article book, and read out—there was plenty of security in shares for that sum, very likely no other security—there was no concealment of any of the directors' transactions—once in a way Sterne may have taken lunch with us at the board; luncheon was always on the table—I will swear I never saw him alone—I asked him to take shares in the London and Mid
dlesex Bank, and we were much obliged for the trouble he took in getting his friends to take shares—I think it very likely I asked him to take shares, but I cannot say positively—Mr. Terry often asked him, in my presence, and I was glad that he did, for we were anxious to establish the bank—I don't recollect that I pressed Sterne to take shares—I have no doubt I thanked him for taking shares—Mr. Sterne and Mr. Terry were very intimate—I was a director of the London and Middlesex, and I took 537 shares in it, it being a condition of the transfer that I should take as many shares in it as I had in the Unity—I sold most of them at a premium of 10s. 6d.—I think the London and Middlesex Bank was given up after twelve months, and nearly the whole capital, amounting to 70,000l., was lost. A. weekly statement like that produced was made to us regularly—it is a printed form; we examined it—the affairs of the west-end branch also came before us in the same form—the item, "Sundries" in the weekly return in
cluded the total of the cash article book—I never looked at the general ledger in my life, and very rarely at the cash article book—we looked very particularly at the weekly statement, and read all the correspondence both in
and out—after the conversation with Burch on the 9th of February, 1864, to which I have spoken, I addressed a meeting of shareholders, on the same day.

Q. Did you say on that occasion, "I think it is necessary that I should distinctly and unmistakably state that the conduct of the directors in the management of this bank has been honest and consistent, and of the utmost regularity?" A. I believe I did—there were very-likely cries of "No, no, "to that—I also said, "Gentlemen, with respect to the staff, the directors have no knowledge of, nor do they believe in any irregularity on the part of the staff of the Unify Bank"—I believed so at the time—it afterwards took Mr. Howell, the accountant, four months to go over the books to ascertain the true state of affairs—I thought it very strange that the defendants should have carried over those accounts without letting us know—it was not at the wish of the bank that I became Sheriff—I don't think I borrowed 600l., to pay my shrievalty expenses; I may have done so—my shrievalty cost me 4, 6002.—if the directors had borrowed all the capital, it would have been for the benefit of the shareholders, and nothing would have been lost.

Q. Did you say this at a meeting of shareholders on 16th July, 1858:—"Allow me to say the directors do not trust entirely either to the clerks or the manager; once a month they count all the cash themselves, each director taking his turn; every Tuesday we examine every bill that is dis
counted, and the particulars of every loan that is proposed; the expenditure also constantly undergoes a most rigid investigation"? A. That is so—the cash was not always counted once a month—that was our duty—it was very often counted—it might in some instances have been omitted—we counted the notes and gold—we verified the cash in the tills.

Q. Do you remember Deputy Bower, one of the directors, saying at the same meeting, "Twice a week, gentlemen, every Tuesday and Friday: I am the more entitled to say this because some question has arisen with regard to a monthly audit of the accounts—twice a week, I say, we might always have been found at our posts: not that our efforts have been confined to those days, but on those days there has been a regular examination made of what has been done in the intervening day. Now, when we have made that ex
amination, and made it, as I know it has been made, correctly; when, and in addition, we have every week made a practical audit by counting the cash, I must say I do not see how any other gentleman coming there monthly could have done the work better than it has been done by ourselves. "A. Yes; he was wrong in saying every week, it was every month—I have no doubt he said so—they are bond fide reports, and copies were seat to all the shareholders—I think it very likely that the shareholders proposed an audit once a month, and very likely the directors opposed it—on 21st January, 1859, I addressed a meeting—I no doubt said, "I think I may very safely congratulate you on the improved state of your affairs through the excellent management of Mr. Terry, combined with the careful supervision of the directors, the bad debts of the past year, instead of being 40,000l., are under 1,000l. It must be borne in mind that we are not in a position to pick our paper; we are not in the position of the old-established banks, who can take in the largest and the best fish, and reject all the small ones. It is, however, the desire and aim, both of the manager and the directors, not so much to extend our business, as to take care that all the business done shall be bond fide, respectable, and legitimate. Let me add to what I have already said, that the directors still abstain from charging any fees for their services to the bank. They are working very hard, attending very closely to their duties, for the present without any remuneration; but

if the bank should succeed, as I believe it will, I am quite sure they will receive a fair remuneration from the shareholders at the proper time. The directors are determined to devote close and untiring attention to your affairs. We have always done so up to the present time; We read every letter, we look at every bill, we devote a good deal of time to your interests, and we shall continue our efforts in the hope that are long they will be crowned with happy results."—That is perfectly true—I have mo doubt I said so, and that I meant so—I heard Deputy Bower say at thai meeting—"You all know that we have stack to the bank; yes, almost like leeches have we stuck to it. We have attended twice a week without any remune ration; we examine everything; we take an interest in everything; there can be no retrogression without our knowledge, and 10 advance without our helping to promote it We come before you with a can did statement of our affairs to the last penny. If there had been any lost we should have informed you of it."—At the half-yearly meeting, on the 27th January, 1860, I said, "Past experience has made us wise. We have learnt mot to place too much confidence in any man. We have got an excellent manager (we take care that all who are employed are not merely testimonial men, but persons who have been tried before), but we shall watch even our manager closely; and I contend that, in a concern of this kind, no man should be entrusted with an unlimited amount of responsibility."That is quite true, and acting on that we appointed Mr. Burch as the eye of the Board—I asked for 3,000l., for remuneration for my services and my losses—there was no doubt consider able discussion about it—I could not say on what day it was—I said without that I would not consent to the transfer to the London and Middlesex, and I was at liberty to do that as a shareholder—none of the directors asked for remuneration—we were to get 10, 00l., by the transfer on a certain contingency, and I asked for 3,000l., of that sum I worked for it, too, and I should have had plenty of sympathy from the shareholdaers, if that had been put into my pockets—the June balance-sheet was no doubt considered at our meetings—we always looked at the balance-sheets and talked them over, but we never altered or interfered with them—I have mo recollection on one occasion, when we wished to have a dividend, Mr. Terry entertaining a strong objection to it—if I stated so in July, 1860, it was so certainly.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINB. Q. Did you say you appointed Burch as Secretary to superintend the manager? A. As the eye of the board—the former manager resigned in 1857—Burch came first as a clerk, and he was afterwards appointed secretary—he had first 160l., and then 200l., a year, and the manager had 500l.,—I consider my duty, as a director, was to direct and supervise, to receive the reports of our confiden
tial officers, and to form opinions on those reports.

Q. And not to inquire any further into the matter. A. I did not say that—on the contrary, I inquired whenever there was in my mind a necessity for inquiry—we certainly did not consider it our duty to look at the books of the bank—they were very numerous and voluminous, but at the Board meet
ings we had all the correspondence read, and we had a weekly statement furnished by our confidential servants—we must have believed what they said, or we must have discharged them—we took their word for the repre
sentation of certain facts—the books were read to us—we looked at the letter-books occasionally—the correspondence was a most important part of the business of the bank—we could not become clerks or managers.
COURT. Q. I suppose you looked at the weekly returns? A. Closely, in all their details—they were our guides, for we did not know what we were about without them.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. Did you take away, or have you got a copy of the weekly return of August, 1862? A. No; I have taken no document away belonging to the bank—I am quite sure I did not take away a return of August, 1862—I have not a single one in my possession.

Q. Did you say at the half-yearly meeting on the 20th July, 1860: "The directors had adopted the prudent policy of endeavouring to do a safe business rather than a very extended one of a less certain character, and he was happy to state as the result, that the losses from bad debts did not ex
ceed the average small amount which had hitherto occurred under the excel
lent management of Mr. Terry. On this, the termination of the third year under the new management, he had looked into the books with the view of ascertaining whether and to what extent they had improved their condition under the new regime, and the result of his inquiry was so favour-able that he ventured to lay a few figures on the subject before the meeting. "Is that true? A. I never said anything but what I believed to be true—I call that looking into the books—it was made by our confidential manager; if you cannot trust him, who can you trust—perhaps I ought to have said I looked into the accounts—I consider that the looking at the weekly state
ments produced to us by the proper authorities was looking into the books—we did not employ a detective over our manager—we had all the bills before us weekly, and every loan that was granted, as far as we knew—there was also produced before us every week what was called the customers' account, showing what persons' accounts were overdrawn, and how much the discount for the week was—we should not have fulfilled our duties if we had not had such an account—I had an account in my own name at the head office—I did not draw on that account, it was merely in connexion with the shares—Mechi and Bazin had an account at the chief office, and also at the West-end branch—Mr. Bazin, my partner, had also a separate account—I did not operate on his account—I think it is very likely that I sometimes used his private account for my own purposes—I knew that at times we overdrew our account at the chief office, and at times at the west branch, but my partner managed the financial department altogether; I had nothing to do with the finances of the business.

Q. Did you bring out the money from that West-end branch and pay it into the chief office to give your account there the appearance of a balance? A. I think at the close of a half-year every one likes to make their balance look pretty well, and on one occasion that was done; but the bank suffered nothing by it—whenever our account was overdrawn I insisted on being charged for it.
Q. Did you do the same thing sometimes to show a balance at the western branch? A. That may have been done; I do not know; my partner managed the financial department.

Q. Did you in that way always appear to have a respectable balance at both? A. Very likely; the cheques passed—my partner managed the financial transactions entirely—I did not interfere; he had the entire management—it was without my authority—I should not have objected to it; it was a very innocent affair—I did know it; but I did not authorise him to do it—I knew it at the time.

Q. So that there would appear a balance at both offices when the balance was against you at both? A. The cheques were passing and would be paid—the appearance of the audit would be that we had a balance in our favour, not very considerable—we were not overdrawing; the cheques were passing.
COURT. Q. Supposing those cheques had not been drawn, would you
appear to have overdrawn at both places? A. I can't say; I am not sure—the cheques were passing to put both accounts in credit, when in fact they were not in credit.

MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE.Q. Was it not done to falsely represent that you had a balance, when in point of fact you were overdrawing? A. I be
lieve it was a very innocent affair—it had that effect—it was done with that intention, no doubt.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. You have mentioned the examination of the books by the directors; will you state exactly what was done when you met on the Tuesday? A. On the Tuesday the loans were considered—they were brought before us for our sanction—there was a loan book, in which was placed the amount granted, subject to approval—those were new loans—Mr. Burch mentioned the name of the person applying for the loan and the amount and sometimes Mr. Terry, and the subject was discussed amongst the directors—the manager was called in when it was necessary to get information on the sub
ject, to enable them to decide—I think the discussion was conducted in the first instance without the manager, but generally with him, and after discus
sion we came to a decision—all loans or renewals were considered on that same day, the Tuesday—the matter was brought before us by Mr. Burch, verbally or in his list; I can't say which; sometimes the name was put down I think, I cannot quite charge my memory; we discussed the question whether it was a proper loan to grant, Mr. Burch being present, and after
wards if any further explanation was wanted we called in Mr. Terry to give us the reasons and grounds for granting the loan—here is an entry on 25th June, 1861: "The following loans were approved"—then follows a list of names—they would not be written until after our decision was arrived at—they were discussed one by one—Mr. Burch would regulate the order in which they were brought before us, then we should discuss them, and on being approved they would be put down—no loans were ever brought before us until the manager bad first approved of them—I think that was our principal business on Tuesday—the correspondence was read on Friday—I know that our meetings were very short on Tuesday compared with Friday—the weekly reports were read on the Friday, I think—on the Friday we had the correspondence read, with the list of discounts—Mr. Burch read the correspondence; that occupied a substantial part of our meeting—we then read the weekly reports of the state of the bank—they were first read and then we examined them ourselves—we examined whether the amount of current accounts, deposit accounts, had increased or diminished; we examined all through it—we perfectly understood it, it was our guide to know in what position we were; we could not have got on at all without that—the cash was counted once a month, I think—I mean the cash in the tills, that is the cash referred to in this item—the bank balance we had before us every week—we banked at the Bank of England—some of us frequently went to the Bank to ascertain that the balance was there correctly—the Bank of England notes were counted by us with our own hands, and the money in the tills—I think the silver was weighed—the gold was counted—we did not attempt to verify the item of sundries—they were cheques and bills in transitu or in suspense, passing into the country for realization and so on—we did not check those, more than the list being read to us—another paper was handed in—that was a paper of discounts; the discounts effected for the week—there is an abundance of these, it is a very important list to us—it was a list of persons requiring discount, how much already had been discounted, what was the average balance, and what the rate of interest—that was part of the business that we managed as directors—we examined each bill that

was discounted—the bills were passed from one director to another to see whether the names were good or not; to see if we knew them, and if not, questions were asked—from two to four hours were occupied in that way at these meetings—it depended upon the length of the correspondence and so on—we did not consider it our duty to look at the books themselves, because we had no doubt of the honesty and straightforwardness of our officials—by our officials I mean the manager, secretary, and accountants—the balance-sheet was brought before us after it had been verified by the auditors—it was then sent to the printers by Mr. Burch or Mr. Terry—we never saw it till then I think—I don't think we saw it before the auditors—it was brought to us immediately before sending it to the printers—it would be submitted to the auditors soon after the accounts were made up at the half-years—I think it occupied the auditors about a fortnight—we never inter
fered at all with the auditors or held any communication with them with respect to their audit—if we happened to go in and found them there, we immediately said, "Good morning, "and went out—after being audited the balance-sheet was submitted as a matter of course to the shareholders, with the auditrs' signatures attached.

COURT. Q. Do you mean to say that you did not see the balance-sheet at all before it was submitted to the auditors? A. It came to us after the auditors—I don't know that I ever saw it before—my brother directors will be able perhaps to speak upon that, but I don't recollect that we ever saw it before; in tact, I don't think it was made up until then—if I bad seen anything wrong in the balance-sheet, it would have been my duty to call attention to it—the re-port was matter of discussion amongst the directors; that was entirely a matter for the directors—that is not the balance-sheet; it is attached to it on the other side of the fly-leaf—the report assumes the balance-sheet to be correct.

MR. GIPFARD. Q. A variety of speeches or portions of them have been suggested to you—I believe you have made a good many of those speeches to the shareholders? A. We considered it our duty that the absent share
holders should know everything, as if they were present, and therefore we had a special reporter, who gave a verbatim report of everything that was said and done, and a copy was transmitted to each shareholder—the speeches were rather long at times—I invariably told the shareholders that I would answer any questions put to me, and those questions and answers are all embodied in the reports—at the time I made those statements that have been referred to, I believed them to be true.
JURY. Q. Were you at any time aware that in that item, No. 3, 207,000l., the full amount of bankrupts' bills and forgeries were iucluded? A. Certainly not; I had no idea of such a thing.

Q. Then I should like to know what directions were given? A. The directions given were to make a true and faithful account of the value, of the estimated value, as far as it could be reached, of each security, without colour and without exaggeration.

COURT. Q. Did you ever look to see what estimate had been made? A. The estimates were discussed frequently in the board-room—in certain cases, in many cases, I inquired of Mr. Terry upon what principle he esti
mated the bills, such as Perl's, for instance—with reference to this account of 30th June, I don't think I did inquire of him upon what principle he had estimated the bills, or the amount at which he had estimated them—I did not understand the over-due bills' account to be estimated in these weekly returns—he was to carry into the balance-sheet the true value.
Q. Comparing the weekly returns with the balance-sheet of 30th June,

Would it not appear from that that the item of 207,000l., was not an estimate? A. I always considered that it was an estimate—I did not know what amount was carried in, as past-due bills; I could not tell without the books—I con
sidered that the bankrupts' bills and forgeries were estimated in the balance
sheet, but in the weekly returns they were put at their true value, as far as it could be reached—I don't think there was any direction to Mr. Terry in writing on this matter—there is a list of the bills somewhere—Mr. Howell has been through the accounts, and can give the details.

MR. HOWELL (re-examined.) Included in tie items of sundries, 19, 471l., is a large number of bills, which have been carried through the cash article book from day to day, and en 29th or 30th June, the bulk of them were disposed of by increasing this amount of 12, 882l.; the amount of past-due bills entered in the general ledger up to 24th June, 1862, at the chief office, to 23,000l., odd; then at the Western branch, the put-due bills is 7, 869l., including 1, 600l., dishonoured; altogether the amount would be about 50,000l.,—the weekly returns contain the whole of the bills and loams over
due, including the bankrupts' bills, forgeries, and so on; on examination that proved to be correct—it has always been the custom to include all that were not written off—nothing else has been written off bet the 38,000l.,—the weekly returns contain everything that is in the hooks in the shape of hills or loans, however hopeless, at their full value—that was laid before the directors every week—an examination would prove What this item con
sisted of.

MR. ALDERMAN MECHI (re-examined) I was not aware that it contained forgeries or anything of that kind—I understood thai the bills and loans in the weekly returns were not estimated, but that in the balance-sheet, issued to the shareholders, they were estimated.

GEORGE LEWIS PHIPPS EYRE . I am A partner in the firm of Byre and Lawson, solicitors, of 1, John-street, Bedford-row—I have been in the pro
fession since the year 1840—at the formation of the Unity Bank I was applied to by Mr. Bayliss to become a director—I was a director from the first—Mr. Terry was appointed first accountant to the bank at the time I was a director—on Mr. Chamber's retirement he became manager—I did not take an active part in his appointment—I remember an instance of a sum of 1,000l., borrowed by a person named Gregory, being entered in the cash article book; that transaction took place before the investigation to the management of the bank by Mr. Chambers—Mr. Gregory had l,000l., lent him by Mr. Chambers, without security—an inquiry was made of Mr. Chambers whether that was not in the cash article book, and there was a ques
tion whether it appeared there or not; Mr. Terry was called into the board-room, and heat once, when asked the question, admitted that it was, and ire
gularly so, inasmuch as Mr. Gregory had left the country, and the money must be considered as lost—that was an irregularity by Mr. Chambens which Mr. Terry pointed out On 24th December, 1657, I wrote this letter to the directors; it is addressed to Mr. Alderman Mechi—(read; "My dear Sir—Sinee our last court-day I have taken into consideration the position of the Unity Bank, and my own responsibilities and duties in connexion therewith. After what has passed, and the small shave of support I received from the chair, I do not feel personally inclined, nor do I see the advantage that would arise from my again attending the court until my duty may impera
lively require ma I desire, however, to put on formal record my view as to our present position, and as to the course which ought to be pursued. You are aware that I hare for some time past regarded the position of the

bank with apprehension. That apprehension has been seriously increased by the recent revelations. The committee appointed at my instance has brought to light larger losses and a far more imperfect system of manage
ment than we were, any of us, previously aware of. The examination has also elicited facts connected with our losses which are of a very serious character. I have ventured to submit to yourself and my colleagues what appears to me to be our only remedy. But while I find my colleagues generally concurring with me as to the serious character of past transactions, I do not find them prepared to take the only step by which, as it seems to me, the property is likely to be saved from ruin. Under such circumstances the grave question which I have to consider is by what course of proceeding I can divest myself of any portion of the serious responsibility which de
volves upon me, and how far I can best perform my duty, not only to those who at my instance have invested their money in the bank, but to all pro
prietors at large who have honoured me with their confidence as a director. There is no ordinary meeting of proprietors until the month of January. The circumstances, however, are so serious that I think it ought to be deliberately considered whether we are to await that period or give the proprietary an opportunity of considering the position of the bank. In the balance-sheet of the 30th of April, 1857, our losses were stated to have been 1, 100l., According to your statement at the court in July, they are now upwards of 10,000l., showing a loss of nearly 9,000l., in three months. The customers' deposits in the bank do not increase; at the present time they would be less than they were six months since had not several thousand pounds been paid in respect of the call of the Unity Fire Company. Our paid-up capital (150,000l.,) has been so dealt with that we have no more than 15,000l.,—one-tenth of the whole—available at the present time for banking purposes. Our shares, of the value of 50l., each, are at the present time not saleable in the share-market. Without reference to the many other grave and startling facts which are known to us, it appears to me that the fore
going considerations alone are sufficient to indicate the propriety of calling our proprietors together. I accordingly request that you will have the kindness to submit this communication to the court, and take its deliberate opinion as to the propriety of calling a special meeting of the proprietors to consider the position of the bank. In the event of any such meeting I shall be prepared to state unreservedly my views of the present position of the property, and at the same time to resign my seat as a director. In the contrary event, I shall, at any rate, feel that I have done my duty by putting on record my protest against the present system of management, and my opinion as to the course which ought to be taken in justice to the pro
prietors.")—At that time I had from thirty-five to forty shares in the bank—at the time I wrote that letter I had ceased to attend the board—I after
wards resumed my seat, and continued to attend ever since down to 1862—I afterwards increased my shares to sixty-nine—I certainly understood the item of 207,000l., in the balance-sheet of June, 1862, to include the past-due bills, taking the latter at the proper estimate of their value—I never ex
amined the item of cash in hand, 38, 781l., nor did I examine some of the other items—I was present at the weekly meetings when the cash-article book was read, and I believed judging now from the large number of names it con
tained, that the items in that book could never have been read over fully—on the 27th of June, 1862, those items were written upon thirteen pages of the book, and the reading of these over would have occupied a much longer time than ten minutes—on 17th December, 1862, a list of the defaulters

and particulars of the past-due bills and other securities was directed to be made out—that list was made, and I took notes at the time of each name it contained, as Burch read them; the names of Lowenthal and Sterne are omitted—Bunyard's name is also omitted, so are those of Jabez Wood and John Harrison—Burch presented a list of the debtors at the time of the stoppage of the bank, in accordance with a resolution—the names just men
tioned were not in that list—on 9th February, 1864, I was with Mr. Alder
man Mechi in the board-room of the London and Middlesex Bank—in con
sequenoe of seeing the names of Lowenthal and Sterne on a list of debtors presented to Alderman Mechi, I asked Burch for an explanation—he said he should prefer Mr. Terry to answer the question—he then went down and fetched Terry into the room, who was asked about them—I said that I was thunder
struck at seeing such names as those of Lowenthal and Sterne before the board—he said that the debts had not been named to us, and in regard to Lowenthal he said that it was to the advantage of the Unity, to which Lowenthal was a debtor; as he should be able to work Lowenthal's account with the London and Middlesex so as to reduce the debt to the Unity—I was a director of the London and Middlesex—we were on our legs at the time, with our hats in our hands, to go to a meeting of the Unity share
holders, and nothing more took place then—I was not present on the subsequent meeting of the London and Middlesex, when a note was taken of what Mr. Terry had said—I knew nothing of the release or assign
ment in the case of Bunyard, or of the assignment of Jabez Wood, or the arrangement with Perl's by the execution of a deed, or that it was about being executed—Perl's matter was discussed at the board from time to time on several occasions—I was not aware that the bills of Ironsides were struck out of the bill-diary of bills due—those bills amounted to 4,000l.,—Lowenthal had a discount account at the London and Middlesex Bank—I was a director at that time, but was not then aware that Lowenthal was a debtor to the Unity; Burch said he was a very good customer, and though the bills were small, they were paid in money, which appeared as if it had come over the counter, which gave me the impression that they were genuine trade bills—I believed the balance-sheet of June, 1862, to be true—I had a loan from the Unity Bank, in 1859, of 1,000l.,—that was in con
sequence of the death of my partner, and it was afterwards reduced to 800l., or 750l.,—I had had accommodation from the Unity from time to time—my whole transactions at the Unity amounted to 57, 714l., and my firm had transactions with it to the amount of 307,000l.,—the accommodation I had at the Unity was given on the ordinary terms, and the loan was secured—I get equally good or better terms at my present bank—in con
sequence of the death of my partner, I was about to transfer my account to the Unity Bank.

Cross-examined by MR. SEBJBANT BALLANTIFTL. Q. Is it a fact that there was a dishonoured bill of yours at the bank? A. No, not dishonoured, but a bill not taken up; it was held over by consent—a client of ours had purchased property, and had not the money to pay; we had to raise the money on a reversionary interest, and he went to the bank for the money: the mortgage was not complete at the time the bill became due, and therefore it stood over until it was completed; and when we got the money, we paid off that particular loan—the amount of that bill was 1, 500l., and the date 10th June, 1859—I do not think it found its way into the category of past-due bills; it was what you call held in suspense—I was a director, and this was my child—the bill got into the cash article book, and I heard it read out every week—it remained there for two months—it was read

out several times, and I made the explanation voluntarily several times that the mortgage was not complete—I will undertake to say that I gave an explanation once, or oftener, from time to time—I knew nothing about the exchange of bills by Mr. Mechi from one bank to the other till it was men
tioned at the Mansion House—I have been a solicitor twenty-five years nearly—I cannot say much for my acquaintance with accounts—the books contain entries of all the bank's transactions; but my belief is that nobody under
stands bank-books but a banker—I became trustee for a large sum—I know perfectly well that, as a director, I am expected to understand something of my business—I understand accounts when they are brought before me—certain books were on the table, but I do not believe there was one from which I could have learned the entire affairs of the bank—the general ledger was not on the table, nor was it in the room, as a rule—I do not know that it was ever called for until I was at the Mansion House; I do not think I ever saw it—I know that there was one—I know that the general ledger ought to contain the whole affairs of the bank—an examination of that ledger would have prevented my issuing a false balance-sheet, but the directors never issued a false balance-sheet—it was not signed by Mr. Mechi I believe—the report was signed by Mr. Mechi—he was not the agent of the directors; but, no doubt, as chairman of the directors, he would sign any report—I consider myself responsible for the report as far as it is correct report—I consider myself responsible, with Mr. Mechi and the other directors, for that act, doubtless—if we had examined the general ledger, I should say that we should have been enabled to send out a true report of the state of the bank instead of a false one—have not looked at the ledger, but as a general rule, I should say yes.

Q. I find on 17th November, 1856, "The accounts of liabilities and assets for October and November at the head office were examined with the general ledger; Present, "among others, "MR. Eyre, "and on that occasion you were in the chair; do you mean, upon the face of that entry, to swear that you never saw the general ledger? A. Certainly not; I made a mistake—having seen that entry, I have no doubt that the general ledger was brought forward, but cannot say whether I examined it; it is nine years ago—I have not the slightest recollection of the fact—I do not know anything about seeing the general ledger—it is obvious that a new bank is not expected to obtain all first-rate customers, and therefore we always went through the securities for loans, and investigated the amounts of the loans—the bills were brought before and after they had been discounted—when the bad debts were brought before us, they were taken into consideration—there was a weekly statement of the affairs of the bank—I took one of them home with me from the Mansion House, but gave it back upon application—that would, I consider, have given me full information upon the affairs of the bank if I had looked into it—I do not know whether it contained all the affairs of the bank, or whether, with its assistance, we should have been able to send out a report free from misrepresentation—it was a general statement, and there were different items—if we had gone minutely into the statement of our secretary, no doubt it would have given us the fullest information—though willing to take the word of our sub
ordinates, I wished the weekly statement to be produced as a matter of form, and that knowledge might be conveyed to the directors on each head—it was on a printed form—it was always read over by Mr. Burch, and the cash article book also—when I said that the cash article book was read in ten minutes I spoke of the average throughout the whole time, for several years

—the secretary sat at the table in full view of me—I cannot understand whether he turned over the requisite number of pages or not—I cannot say whether he turned over two leaves at a time, or skipped half a dozen accounts.

Q. Can you say that he could not have read all those thirteen pages; that he did not turn them over? A. I can not—I am not here to impute any
thing to anybody—I never had the curiosity to look into the book, as far as I can recollect—it was the cash article book—it was left on the table—I mean to say that when Mr. Burch came before us with a list of defaulters, the names of Lowenthal and Harrison were not read out—I cannot see how the cash article book could in any way have altered my judgment about the state of the bank—I cannot answer the question—the cash article book was laid on the table with the rest of the papers, and the porter would come and take it from the board-room to the secretary's room—I am not aware that there was any concealment of it.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT PARRY. Q. Were not you yourself in the habit of remaining in the board-room after the board had broken up, and ex
amining the books? A. Certainly not—I never did so, to my recollection—the cash article book is a very important one—I paid great attention to it while Mr. Chambers was there, in consequence of his looses it was brought into the room before the directors, and each item was pointed out to Mr. Terry—he showed great moral courage in stating that the transaction of 1,000l., was irregular, and we had great confidence in Mr. Terry's truthful
ness—I did not myself always look at the cash article book; I never did, to my recollection—I knew the nature of it, and that it treated of matters which it might be doubtful whether they might be realized or not; but it was done by a person who we had great confidence in, from the first to the last article, and why should I wish to look at it?—I should say I never looked at it, because I conceived it had all been read through—the weekly statement was read over by Mr. Burch, and looked at by me—I suppose that in this item of 207, 688l., odd, the past-due bills were included; I believe they were—I do not know it from examination; I know it now—my know
ledge was from being informed in the board-room that such was the case, such is the case—with that full knowledge, the balance-sheet of 1862, was issued to the shareholders by me and my brother directors—it never occurred to me to pass these past-due bills as a separate item in the balance-sheet, for the information of the shareholders, nor to any of my brother directors, that I know of—it was never suggested that it should be done, to my recollection—I think I must have seen the discount-book and letter-book—I don't recollect having seen the cash article book—it is true that on 11th March, 1859, I reported that I had visited the West-end branch, and that the manager appeared to be of opinion that the branch was making a little progress—on 3d August, 1860, I reported that I had visited the West-end branch, and checked the cash and notes, and that those amounts agreed with the corresponding entries in the usual weekly returns—on 10th May, 1861, "Deputy Bower reported having visited the Lambeth branch on Wednesday last, Mr. Eyre reported that he visited the West-end branch on 9th instant, when the manager, notwithstanding the heavy amount of past-due bills, expressed his conviction that there was a good sound business now being done at the branch"—in May, 1861, I was aware that there was a heavy amount of past-due bills—I was at one of the meetings when the balance
sheet of September, 1862, was discussed—I was at the second meeting; it was not discussed; it was put down on the table; it had been discussed, and approved—I made a claim for a sum when this bank was established—

I don't know whether it was l,000l.,—I may have told Mr. Chambers that I expected 1,000l., as a promoter of the bank; I can't recollect—very likely I told Mr. Chambers I had a claim—no doubt I told him I expected to get a bonus; I can't Hay of 1,000l.,; I will not swear it was Dot—I am speaking of a time when the bunk was prosperous—we were all asked, and did pay 1,000l., to start the bank, and it was on that ground we thought we should get a bonus—by "we, "I mean the directors—I can only judge for myself—it was expected there would be a bonus—I never got it.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. Has the 1, 500l., been paid? A. Yes; I do not owe anything to the bank—I never made anything in the nature of a claim from the bank—the matter was discussed before the bank came into existence; it was proposed in a clause of the deed to give certain bonuses to the promoters—I knew that the 207,000l., comprehended past-due bills—I did not know that it comprehended forged bills—I considered that the past-due bills were at their proper estimate, that that was the value of the bills.

JURY. Q. Did you know whether bills due from bankrupts' estates were put at their full value? A. I always supposed that they were estimated by the manager at their proper value, and so dealt with as assets.

COURT. Q. Did you ever inquire at what amount be had estimated the bills, and the principle upon which he did it? A. No; I did not—I did not know that the over-due bills in the weekly returns included all the over
due bills, bankrupts' bills, and others; of course it included those bills that were in suspense—I understood that the over-due bills included bankrupts' bills—I assumed that they were put down in the weekly returns as in sus
pense, at their full value; I never made the inquiry—I considered that the forgery bills were there, and I supposed the bankrupts' bills were—I supposed it embraced those bills where the estates of the parties were in liquidation—I supposed that it contained every bill that had not been paid from the time the 28,000l., had been written off.

WILLIAM GOULD . I was from the first a shareholder in the Unity Bank—I am an iron merchant—I kept a private account at the bank—I never had any accommodation—I was one of the auditors who audited the balance
sheet of June, 1862—I used to have notice from the bank that the balance
sheet would be ready by a certain day; I would then call, and Mr. Terry would produce certain books—the secretary used to call the totals from the books—my colleague in the auditorship was a professional accountant, who was appointed expressly by the shareholders—what the item of 207,000l., was composed of I knew not.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT BALLANTTNE. Q. Are you acquainted with figures? A. Not with accounts, only buying and selling iron—my colleague was an excellent practical accountant—the books of the bank were readily produced, and there was not the slightest disinclination shown by the officials to produce anything that was required—I was two hours at the bank for two days in succession auditing the accounts, the scientific details I left entirely in the hands of my colleague.

BENJAMIN BOWER , Esq. Deputy. I am deputy of the ward of Billingsgate, and a member of the Court of Common Council—I am a wholesale fruiterer, carrying on business in Lower Thames-street—I was one of the directors of the Unity Bank—I joined it eleven months after it opened, that was before Mr. Chambers seceded from the management—I knew of the losses that had occurred to the bank during his management when I became a director—I joined the board in October, 1856, and remained a director till the last—I also became a director of the London and Middlesex Bank—my

shares were transferred from the Unity—I alto took 100 shares besides—I always attended the half-yearly meetings of the Unity Board—I remember the balance-sheet of 30th June, 1862, being presented in September, 1862—I was present at the board meeting when the report was agreed to—I had no knowledge that the forged and dishonoured bills were pat on the creditor side of that balance-sheet—that was not done with my knowledge or sarc
tion in any way; I was too deeply interested in the success of the bank to, have sanctioned such a thing—I purchased five more shares in August, 1861, at 16l., per share—at the time the business was passed over to the London and Westminster, I had some conversation with Mr. Burch; it was a few days before it was actually transferred; I can't give the date—I asked Mr. Burch to supply me with a paper specifying all the assets which constituted the value of the bank—he furnished me with a long slip of paper—this it it, there is some of my writing upon it (read) "City, 105,000l., and 42,000l.; West, 22,000l., and 5,000l.; loans, 6,000l., and 3,000l.; total, 183,000l.," at the bottom of the page, "City, 190,000l.; loans and discount, 33,000l.; cash, 8,000l.; Brighton, 15,000l.,"—on the other side, against that amount, is put, "Good-will and furniture West, 20,000l.; loans and discounts, 3,000l.; cash, 1, 500l.; total, 270, 500l.; deductions, 183,000l., leaving 87, 800l.,"—at the time I received that I made a memorandum on the back in Burch's pre
sence—he saw it—the memorandum is, "Confident of 8,000l., clear"—that was my note—the object of it was to ascertain how much per share was likely to be paid to the shareholders of the Unity Bank, and I reckoned it at 30l., per share—I remember Mr. Eyre making certain suggestions as to the management of the bank—I was present at the time the board adopted those suggestions; I was always present if I was able, and I seldom passed within the neighbourhood without looking in to see if I could be of any use—I had nothing to do with the preparation of the balance-sheet in question—I knew that it was printed and circulated amongst the shareholders—I had no reason to doubt the correctness of that balance-sheet—I saw the detailed balance-sheet on the table; it was handed round—we all looked at it—I have no doubt I saw it—I was present—I think we had two meetings; at one it was in a rough state, and at the other it was in a mere perfect state—that is according to my recollection of it—I presume this is it (looking at it), I should not like to swear it—I think it is most likely that both balance-sheets were on the table—I know I saw the one that was published to the shareholders.

Cross-exammed by MR. SERJEANT BALLANTINE. Q. And you have no doubt that you saw the other also, have yon? A. If it was on the table I saw it—I have looked at it now—I can't speak to any recollection of figures—I can't undertake to say this is one of those I saw; if it came before the board I saw it along with the rest—I can't say that I did see it, and I won't deny it—I don't know that I did see it, really cannot say—I have a doubt about it—I said I had seen two balance-sheets; whether this is one I cannot tell—I did not say I had seen the detailed balance-sheet, I don't know that I did—I said that upon each occasion I saw a balance-sheet—you may put in the word detailed, if you please—I won't swear this is the one—I have no doubt I did see one more in detail than the other, but whether this is the one I could not undertake to say—I saw two balance-sheets—I saw what is called a detailed balance-sheet—I know the distinction between the de
tailed balance-sheet and the other—I think Alderman Mechi estimated the shares at 30l., but I depended more upon this paper; I don't recollect what he said; Alderman Mechi talks very fast sometimes—in the estimate of these
shares I don't think the 10,000l., that was expected from the London and Middlesex Bank was included—perhaps it was; no doubt it was.
MR. GIFFARD. Q. What is your age? A. I am seventy-seven and a half.

Q. Was the balance-sheet, which you saw, detailed or general, signed by the auditors? A. I think not; I won't say positively; I think it is very probable that it was—I have no positive memory one way or the other—I don't recollect anything about the word "detailed"—there was a balance-sheet in a very rough state laid before us; that was the balance-sheet prepared by the manager and secretary—I think there were less figures in the final one—it was a short time before the half-yearly meeting that I saw it—(looking at the detailed balance-sheet again)—I can't say whether I ever saw this document before.

JURT. Q. Had you any knowledge of the forged and bankrupt bills being in the item of 207,000l.,? A. I did not know anything about them till all of a sudden we found these things were in existence; I had no knowledge of them before.

COURT. Q. Did you understand that there were overdue bills in that item? A. No, I had no suspicion that such a thing was done—there might be overdue bills which were of some value, as we supposed—I did not know whether there were bills of bankrupts—bills are supposed to be of some value for a long time; in that way I might consider they appeared, but certainly not at their value as put upon paper—I did not consider they appeared in any other form than this, that some value is attached to a bad bill, if it is only 1s. in the pound, and that is customary sometimes in banks, I believe; at least so I understand.

JURY. Q. Were, you at any time aware that forged bills and bankrupts' bills were included in that 207,000l.,? A. Certainly not—bills which are not paid when they become due, may be paid afterwards; they may pay 10s. in the pound, or something—I did understand that they were valued at something, but in no other way; if I had had a suspicion of it I should have been frightened out of my senses.

COURT. Q. Did you know that the weekly statements contained the list of all the bills that had accumulated since the 38,000l., was written off? A. I believe no such information was given to us—I did not know it—I never gave my sanction to anything of the sort—I certainly did not believe, nor had I the least suspicion, that bills that were good for nothing, were brought there at their full value—I did not know in what way the over due bills were treated in the weekly returns; and if I and my colleagues had known I think we should have stopped it.

Q. Did you ever give directions that forgeries and bankrupts' bills should be only estimated, and not put down at their full value? A. I never gave any particular directions about it, but I always understood that was the way in which it was done in all banks—the bills always were estimated—I never saw it done in any account in the bank.

THOMAS CARLYLE HAYWARD . I am a merchant in the Minories—I was one of the directors of the Unity Bank—I became so in 1855—I subse-quently became a director of the London and Middlesex Bank—I was not aware that forged bills were included in this item of 207,000l.,—I con-sidered that bankrupts' bills were so reckoned by our manager—I considered that all past-due bills were valued by our manager at a percentage, according to their value—I took my last shares in December, 1861, paying 22l. per share—I did not confer with Mr. Terry entirely upon my purchase of those shares, but I took their value from the assets of the bank—I

thought they would be worth 30l., a share, consequently I gave that money for them I thought in safety—I recollect hearing a conversation between Burch and Mr. Eyre, at least Burch was called into the committee-room when I was a director of the Lon
don and Middlesex bank—I recollect a paper or a list of debts that Mr. Eyre observed Alderman Mechi had before him; and Mr. Eyre observing the names of Lowenthal and Sterne there, expressed a good deal of surprise, and so did we all—I was present when the minute of this was taken, on 9th February, 1864, it was read over to Terry—(Read "At a meeting of the directors of the London and Middlesex bank, limited; present T. C. Hay ward, and others—the directors having ascertained that when the Unity Bank transferred its business to the London and Middlesex bank, the following persons were debtors to the Unity Bank: Lowenthal, 3, 500l.; and Sterne, 1, 700l.; and that Mr. Terry con
cealed those debts from the directors of the London and Middlesex bank, and advised them to discount bills for those two persons to a considerable extent, which were discounted accordingly, and the amount remains due; thereupon Mr. Terry made a statement to the following effect: 'It is per
fectly true, there is no doubt about it; there was no fear of losing from them—we discounted for other persons in the same way—I worked Low
enthal's bills down considerably before the Unity bank transferred its busi
ness—the Unity bills had all matured when the London and Middlesex dis
counts were given—as to Sterne, he was instrumental in forming the London and Middlesex bank—I said I should bring his debt before the board, but he said he should settle it all, as he wished to stand well with the board—he only got accommodation when he began to run up the shares—the acceptances of 1, 750l., which I gave him on deposit of bank-shares, was signed by the secretary and myself, without any authority from the direc
tors—the intimation given me by Mr. Cooper, not to make advances to Sterne, was after the advances were made—as to Lowenthal, I discovered eighteen months before the Unity bank transferred its business, that he had given accommodation bills, but his acceptances to the Unity were much reduced, from 7,000l., to 1, 500l., before the transfer—as to both, I considered that I was justified in concealing the facts from the directors, because I thought the bills would be paid—that was a mistake, no doubt about it, that I gave the discounts.' "The directors present at that meeting were, Mr. Harris, in the chair, Mr. Benjamin Bower, Mr. Alderman Mechi, Mr. Eyre, MR. Hay ward, and Mr. L. Davis; and Mr. Olabon, and Mr. Boy, the two solicitors.

Cross-examined by MR. SERJEANT PARRY. Q. Is Mr. Tayloe your solicitor? A. He is joint-solicitor with Mr. Clabon—Mr. Tayloe was solicitor to the Unity—he was not constantly present at the board-meetings; he was sometimes—instructions were given to him to sue for overdue accounts—I presume that he was acquainted with all the accounts that were overdue—I saw these weekly statements—I did not see the detailed balance-sheet, to my recol
lection; the balance-sheet that was published I saw—I suppose there was a detailed balance-sheet agreeing therewith.

COURT. Q. Is it the usual course to have a detailed balance-sheet? A. Yes—I have no doubt that a general balance-sheet, and a detailed balance-sheet were handed to the directors; I cannot charge my memory with this—we had the profit and loss balance-sheet, and the general balance
sheet together, but as to the details I cannot undertake to say that the full detailed balance-sheet was there.
Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. You say that the bad debts are

estimated, do you mean by that, that you put a bill of A B for 200l., at 1,000l., or something in that way? A. I should think so—I don't know that there was any particular direction required for that; it was the mana
ger's province to estimate; he gave us his estimate of the overdue bills—he had directions to that effect; of course it was for him to give the esti
mated value—I imagine directions were given him, I have no data to guide me as to when; it was a well understood fact—(Mr. Howell: There is no 1 such statement in any of the books that I have read through)—I cannot give an instance where a bill of any kind was put down at a reduced value—Mr. Burch remained in the London and Middlesex bank a considerable time after the conversation that has been read, I think until August, 1864—he then went to the Lands' Securities—I don't know as to his being recommended; I believe he went at a largely increased salary of 400l., a year—I don't know that Alderman Mechi and Lord Torrington, the chair
man of the London and Middlesex, recommended him very highly; they had a high opinion of him I know, and so had I.

COURT. Q. Did you know that in the weekly statements all the over
due bills appeared which had accumulated from the time the 38,000l., had been written off? A. I presumed so—I presumed that that statement con
tained the whole of those bills, whether bankrupt bills or not—I don't know that they also included forged bills; it is very possible—I think they included all the past-due bills of every description, forged or not, at their full value.

ROBERT PROCTOR . I am a cheesemonger, and was a shareholder in the Unity Bank—I am appointed by the shareholders as liquidator, and was appointed one of the audit committee to go into the question of how the bank got into its present condition, and to investigate the balance-sheet—the defendants attended before us, at the latter end of February or the I beginning of March—surprise was expressed to Terry that statements were put in the balance-sheet which appeared so false and wrong—he said that he had followed the custom of other joint-stock banks in London; I asked him if he had any instructions from the directors as to the manner in which he should prepare the balance-sheet; he said his instructions were only general, and were conveyed to him through Alderman Mechi, that he was to prepare a true and correct balance-sheet—Burch was asked several ques
tions on the subject, and said that he had followed the directions of Mr. Terry in putting down the items, and that he did not consider it his duty to estimate their value—I asked him whether if he had been the manager he would have felt justified in placing such items in the balance sheet, and he said that he should not—we were investigating for the share
holders generally; we were considered antagonistic to the directors, but I do not know upon what grounds—after this investigation the report was adjourned to a meeting of the co-liquidators—the balance-sheet of June 30, was generally circulated among the shareholders, and I received a copy.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. When was the resolution to prose
cute? A. In November—the defendants never said in my hearing that the directors were the persons who were responsible for the way in which this was done.

WILLIAM FEW (examined by MR. SERJEANT PARRY.) Q. Did you act as solicitor to Mr. Bunyard? A. Yes—I have produced the trust deed of composition entered into by him, and signed by Mr. Terry, as manager of the bank—I was perfectly familiar with Mr. Bunyard's affairs at that time

—I saw some bonds, called Micklam bonds, in Mr. Tayloe's hands—there is a bill now pending in the House of Lords which will make them good or bad, according to how the House of Lords decide on a question of Scotch law—they have been treated by other clients of mine at valuable securities, and dealt with as such—they are chargeable on estates in Scotland—Bunyard gave them to the bank in October—I did not go to Mr. Terry for the execution of the trust deed; I think Mr. Terry might have considered that he was right—I considered that it was the best way of dealing with the estate.

MR. GIFPARD. Q. The best thing for Mr. Bunyard? A. For the creditors generally; it was supposed that a large surplus would have been realized, which would have paid the debts in full; at present those securities are not realized—there has been no dividend made yet—besides those bonds, there is security to the amount of 9,000l., upon which they have a claim of 6,000l.—the creditors are "nursing" the securities—there was also a sum of 200l. in the Bankruptcy Court, which was swallowed up in costs—un
less the House of Lords reverse the latest decision, the bonds are worth nothing—Mr. Micklam has since gone into the Bankruptcy Court, but that does not affect them, because they are real estates, and 16,000l. has been voted to carry the question through the House of Lords—Mr. Chidley is the solicitor to the appeal—we thought it more prudent to have a composition deed to carry the matter out of the Bankruptcy Court.

p.rs:
NOT GUILTY—THE JURY stated "We acquit the defendants of conspiracy, but we consider the accounts were kept on a vicious principle; we further con
sider it was a part of the duty of the director* to have investigated further into such accounts, and more particularly the weekly and half yearly balance-sheets."

p.hi: An acquittal was taken as to Terry on the first twenty-four counts of the indictment.

div1.p:
468.
JANE SMITH (20)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

HANNAH SHIP . I am barmaid at the Smiths' Arms beer-house, Plaistow—the prisoner came there on the 22d of February for a pint of ale—she put down a five-shilling piece—I took it to Mr. Makepeace, the landlord, and when I came back the prisoner had gone, without taking the jug of ale—MR. Makepeace followed her and brought her back.

ROBERT MAKEPEACE . The last witness brought me a five-shilling piece; it was bad—I ran down stairs—the prisoner had gone—I ran about 250 yards, and then saw her—she was putting something below her clothes—I said, "You are the party that came to my house for ale"—she said, "No"—I took her back to the bar, and Hannah Ship said she was the person—I then gave her into custody.

MICHAEL PHILLIPS (Policeman, K 198.) I took the prisoner into custody—I received this crown-piece from the last witness—the prisoner was searched at the station—a purse and two halfpennies were found upon her.

SUSAN LEETE . My father keeps a chandler's shop in the Gurney-road, Plaistow—the prisoner came to his shop on the 8th February—I served her with a half-quartern loaf, which came to 3d.—she gave me a five-shilling piece—I gave her the change—I gave the crownpiece to my father, and he
found it was bad—I went out to see if I could find the woman, but could not—I am sure the prisoner is the person.
MR. LEETE. My daughter gave me the crown-piece, and I found it was bad—I went and told a policeman.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months .

469.
HENRY FREEMAN (20)
,
PLEADED GUILTY to unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.—
Confined Nine Months ,

470.
JAMES RICHARD CRAMPTON (33), was indicted
for bigamy.

JOHN HACKING (Policeman, K 216). On the 22d of March, at half-past 10 at night, I was on duty at Ilford—the prisoner came to me accompanied by a young woman—he said he had come to give himself up for bigamy—I asked him why he did so, and he said he was "hard up," and had had nothing to eat that day; he had been to New York, and could get no em
ployment—I asked him where his wives lived, and he said one lived at 26, Richardson-street, Borough, and went to the church at St. John's, Waterloo on the 3d of March—I got a certificate of marriage, which I compared with the books in the church—this is a true copy (produced.)

ALICE HARRIS . I have a daughter named Fanny Louisa—on 3d July, 1853, I was at the church of St. John's, Waterloo, and saw my daughter married to the prisoner—my daughter is alive—I saw her last night.
Prisoner. Q. Did not your daughter go and live in adultery with another man? A. Yes, when you deserted her.

COURT. Q. Had she any children by the other man? A. No—the pri
soner went to the Crimea in 1855, and he returned and claimed his wife in 1862—my daughter did not give him into custody—she, does not wish to have any claim upon him.

LOUISA ROYSTON HILL . I live at 4, Frederick-place, Little Ilford—on the 6th of March, 1864, I was married to the prisoner—I had a certificate—I lived with him up to the 14th of November, when he left, and went to New York—he came back again on the 3d of last March.

Prisoner. Q. Do you recollect going to Richardson-street to see my first wife? A. I do; I said that I loved you, and would marry you again if you could get a divorce—you were always a good husband to me, and I would marry you again.

GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One week.

471.
JAMES HAYDEN (29)
, Rape on
Lydia Johnson.
NOT GUILTY .

472.
WILLIAM ELLIOTT (22)
,
PLEADED GUILTY to embezzling and stealing 1/1.2s. 4 1/2 l., and 4s. of
William Clark.—
Confined Nine Months;

473.
ROBERT RIVERS (31)
, to embezzling and stealing the sums of 3s. 9 1/2 d., 1l. 2s. 5 1/2 d., and 18s. 8 1/2 d., the monies of
Samuel Beenton.— Confined

474.
JAMES RICHARDS (81)
, to Stealing 6 fowls of
David Cookie, and 2 frocks, and other articles, of
William John Compton.—
Confined Eighteen Months. and
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

475.
WILLIAM BAKER (26)
, to stealing 1 oil-skin, and other articles, of
John Small, and others.—
Confined Nine Months.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

476.
JOSEPH SMITH (18)
, Stealing 4 shirts, the property of
Thomas Wilson.

THOMAS WILSON . I am a draper, living at 65, Wellington-street, Wool
ner standing at the corner of the window peeping through a guard—I saw him make a move in the direction of the counter—I went up to him, and asked him what he wanted—he appeared confused—he said, "I want a penny worth of thread"—I served him with it—directly he had gone, I found these shirts wrapped up in this handerchief—the handkerchief smelt of polish or vaanish—the shirts were my property—I went after the prisoner—he had got about fifty or sixty yards when I caught him—I brought him back, and said, "I want you respecting those shirts you have taken"—he said, "I beg your pardon; I hope you are not going to account me of taking them?"—I gave him in charge.

Cross-examined. Q. Was not the prisoner outside the shop when you first saw him? A. No; in the lobby—the shirts were about seven or eight feet from the lobby—I did not say a word to him about the shirts when he was in the shop.

SAMUEL LING (Policeman, R 109) I was called by the last witness to take the prisoner into custody—I found the shirts on the floor, wrapped up in this handkerchief—I told the prisoner that I should take him in charge for stealing four shirts—I asked him what he was, and he said a French-polisher—I noticed his hands were covered with polish—I examined the handkerchief, and found stains upon it—it smelt of polish—the handkerchief has now lost its smell, but the stains are visible.

GUILTY .**—
Confined Eighteen Months.

477.
JOHN GROOM,
Stealing a mare, the property of
George Heath.

GEORGE HEATH . I live at Rushy-green, Lewisham, and am a cattle dealer—on the 7th February I turned four horses out to graze in a field in Stansted-lane, Lewisham—one was a grey mare—at 4 o'clock in the after
noon on the 8th February I saw them safe in the field, and on the 10th the grey mare was gone—she is worth about 10l.—I next saw the mare in Mr. Peplow's possession on 22d February.

JESSE SAMUEL SIMPSON I live at Bell-green, Lewisham—I have known this field in Stansted lane for twelve years—I had charge of the horses for Mr. Heath—the grey mare was in the field on the night of the 9th of February.

JOHN PEPLOW . I am a cab proprietor, of Cumberland-place, Old Kent-road—on the 10th February, about 11 in the morning, the prisoner came to me—he had a grey mare with him, and he asked me if I would buy it—he said he wanted 4l. 10s. for her—I said I could not give him so much, as it was very lame, but I would give him 2l. 10s—he said he came by her by "chopping" with a baker at Plumstead for a pony—he said the mare had been turned out on Plumstead marshes.

Prisoner. Q. Did not I agree to take the mare back again? A. Yes, but I told you I was not going to sell her—you did not tell me you had ex
changed her at Croydon-market.

ALFRED JOHN CROUCH (Policeman, R 92). I apprehended the prisoner on 21st February at Deptford—I told him it was for stealing a horse on the Thursday week previous—he said he had changed a pony for the grey mare at Croydon-market—I asked him to describe the man, and he said he was a man of about five feet six or seven inches, who wore a billycock hat, and a long gown—on the road to the station I asked him what he said to the party he sold it to, and he said he told him he had got it of a baker at Erith.

GUILTY .—*
Confined Twelve Months.

478.
ELLEN SMITH (31)
