, Stealing 7 rugs, 1 blanket, and other articles, the property of
Mark Costello.
MR. CUNNINGHAM conducted the Prosecution,

MARGARET COSTELLO . I am the wife of Mark Costello, and reside at Nile-street, Woolwich—the prisoner lodged with me in September last—I used to employ her to assist me in doing some cleaning—on the 8th of September I sent her to fetch some soda—she did not return—from what a lodger said to me, I went and looked over my things, and I missed seven counterpanes, a child's petticoat, and a cape—I saw some of the things at Mrs. Hake's afterwards.

CAROLINE HALSE . I am the wife of James Halse, and reside at 29, Church-street, Woolwich—my husband keeps a wardrobe-shop—I remember the hopseason—about that time the prisoner came into my shop—she asked me to purchase these things (produced), which I did, and paid her 5s. 10d.—she had been to my shop on previous occasions—Mrs. Costello came to me and I showed her the things—I did not see the prisoner again until she was in custody.

RHODA MAINE . I am the wife of Robert Maine, and reside at 29, Church-street, Woolwich, with my sister, the last witness—I was in the shop on the day the prisoner came in and brought these things—I am sure she is the woman.

CHARLES CARTWRIGHT (Policeman, R 101). On the 30th of March last, I took the prisoner into custody—I told her she was charged with stealing some things about September last, she said, "I never took any of the property, but I would rather pay for it than to go prison."

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

479.
JOHN SMITH (47)
, Stealing two coats, the property of
Joseph Mendez.

JOSEPH MENDEZ . I am a clothier at 142, High-street, Woolwich—on 17th February, about 2 in the day, the prisoner came into my shop for a pair of boots, and I said I had none to suit him, as I was in a hurry to go, and I left the shop—this is my coat (produced..
Prisoner. I was in Deptford all that day, I was not in your shop at all. Witness. He is the person—he is rather paralysed—I can swear to him.

REBECCA MENDEZ . I am the prosecutor's daughter—on 17th February 1 hung two coats on the inside of our shop—the prisoner came in between 3 and 4 on that day, and asked if I had a coat and waistcoat to sell him—I shoved him one at 7s. 6d.—he said it was too dear, and I put it on the

shelf again—I saw the two coats that were afterwards missed, hanging up in the shop while the prisoner was there—he did not purchase anything—he asked me if there was anybody at home, and I said no—some information was given to me between 6 and 7 by Mr. Prior, and I found the coats were gone.

BENJAMIN PRIOR . I live at 28, Artillery-place, Woolwich, and am an eating house keeper—on 17th February I saw the prisoner standing at Mendez's door—I went next door to speak to a party, and presently I saw the prisoner come away from the shop into the road putting a coat on—that coat has not been found—it was not this one—I think it was a frock coat—I could not see, because it was dark—I saw him ran away, and I went to the shop—I am positive the prisoner is the man.

MARTHA BORER . I am the wife of James Borer, of 90, High-street, Woolwich—on 17th February the prisoner came to my shop just upon 6 in the evening, with this coat on, and asked me if I would purchase it—I said, you must give me your name and address—he said, "My name is Thomas Sutton, and I have just come in from Gravesend, and I am going to lodge at Uncle Tom's, I have bought my bed there"—I then bought the coat of him for 4s.—about a fortnight afterwards the prisoner came and said, "Have you got a coat to sell, I should like to buy that pilot coat I sold to you some time ago"—I said by way of excuse, "You shall have the coat, "and I sent for Mr. Mendez—I saw a policeman passing and called him in—I had received some information—I afterwards showed him this coat and he identified it.
Prisoner. Q. Can you swear I was the man who came to your shop? A. Yes, positively.

ROBERT HICKMAN (Policeman, R 172). I was called in, and took the prisoner into custody—I asked him where he got the coat from—he said he had bought it—I asked him who from—he said he did not know—he said, "Don't take me into custody, I will pay the 4s. back"—he gave his name as John Smith—I found a discharge from the army on him, with the name of Sutton on it—I asked him if that was his name and he said, "Yes"

GUILTY .—
Confined Two Months.

480.
HUGH COSTON (23)
,
PLEADED GUILTY to stealing a gelding ass, the property of
William Barnes.

GUILTY.—
Confined Six Months.

481.
JOSEPH HARRISON (27), and
GEORGE BROOKS (45)
, stealing 20 pieces of leather and two blankets, the property of
Her Majesty the Queen.
MESSRS. COOPER and POLAND conducted the Prosecution, MR. HARRY PALMER defended Harrison, and MR. LILLET defended Brooks.

JOHN RANDALL . I a detective stationed at Woolwich—on Thursday night, 23rd February, about 9 o'clock, I went to the Union beer-house in the Gardens at Woolwich, kept by the prisoner Brooks, with Serjeant
Major Osborn and Crouch a detective—I found Brooks there—I called him outside and asked him if he had bought any leather from a bombardier of the artillery on Tuesday last—he said, "No"—I then asked him if he had got any Government leather in his house—he said, "No"—I said, "Will you allow us to look over your house, to see if you have any"—he said, "Yes"—we went into the house into a room on the right hand, kept as a harness shop—I there found this half of a hide of leather (produced), underneath a working bench—I also found in different parts of the shop

these several other pieces—I saw the Government mark upon the leather, though very indistinct, and a number of places where something had been erased—it was "W. D.," War Department—I said to the prisoner, "How do you account for having this Government leather in your possession"—he said, "I bought it of a harness maker near Sandy-hill, Plumstead, near the Fox and Hounds"—he gave a name, but I am not able to recollect it—he said he borrowed 2l. from Mr. Vaughan, a builder, who lived next to the Fox and Hounds, to help to pay for it—we found some reins and several other things—there is a very indistinct mark on the reins, not so plain as the other—after searching down stairs, I said to Brooks, 'Now have you toy mere leather up stairs"—he said, "No"—I went up stairs in company with Osborn and a friend of Brooks' and in his private bedroom I found this skin of leather, with the broad arrow stamped upon it—I came down and said, "I have found some more in your bed-room Brooks"—he made no reply—I then told bin I should take him into custody for receiving a quantity of leather from a bombardier of the Royal Artillery, well knowing ii to be stolen—he made no answer.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Where is the mark of which you speak? A. At the edge, it is very slight—it is in much the same state as it was when I found it—it will wear off by being pulled about—I have been stationed at Woolwich fifteen years—I am aware that sales of Govern
ment stores frequently take place—I believe it is the case on some occasions that new things are sold, but I never saw any like these—the things that are sold bear the usual mark in some cases—they are sold occasionally in large quantities to one bidder—the sales take place at the Royal Arsenal—they comprehend nearly all sorts of stores, I think; condemned stores—condomned stores do not always necessarily mean things that are worn out but condemned in the service—I have known Brooks seven or eight years—daring that time, as far as I know, he has borne the character of an honest man.

MR. COOPER. Q. I suppose you don't know much about what condemned stores are? A. I have seen a great many sold but I am not acquainted with them much—I went to the Fox and Hounds and looked for an harness
maker—I could not find one there—I also called upon Mr. Vaughan—I found a blanket in Brook's bedroom—this is it (produeed), it has a very slight mark on it.
MR. LILLEY. Q. Look at that piece of leather and see if that has a Government mark? A. Yes; I have seen a great quantity of that sold, but never like this.

JOHN OSBORN . I am a sergeant-major in the Royal Artillery, stationed at Woolwich—I went with the last witness to Brooks' house, and saw the whole of this leather found—I have examined this leather and on these two pieces I find the Government mark, and several marks which appear to have been erased—I find the remains of the "W. D." on one piece and this piece is marked plainly. (Pointing it out),—I put these ink rings round them to point them out better—I have looked at an old piece called quarter leather, that is marked as well—these two blankets were found in the bed-room, they were marked with the Government mark in the centre, the mark is apparently out of this one, but it is a Government blanket—there is a mark on this other one, you can't see it unless you hold it up to a bright light, it is "W. D." and a broad arrow, all Government blankets are made with the selvage in this way, the W. D. is a mark that has been used since the Crimean war,; formerly they were marked "B. O," and the broad

arrow—at the latter end of 1857 the W. D. blankets were need—we never sell new leather like this, the things that are sold are all old stores from All parts of the world, belonging to Government, which are brought to the Royal Arsenal to the store-keeper's department—they are there examined, and if repairable they are repaired and used, no new stores become obsolete, new material is never sold.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Have you never seen blankets sold? A. No; I know they are sold, I have not been present at sales, but I know that all blankets that are sold are torn into four pieces—I don't know that Brooks served in the Crimea, except from his own statements—no man was allowed to have more than one blanket—I have examined those reins; the mark is simply impressed, they are stamped before they are made—this leather has been blackened since the hide has been out, and it is blackened on the wrong side.

WILLIAM ENDON . I am a driver in the Royal artillery—on 21st February I was in the officers' kitchen, employed as a servant to an officer—I saw Harrison on that day between twelve and one, in the kitchen—I saw a roll of brownish leather about six feet long lying in the kitchen—Harrison asked a woman who was there, if she would take the leather out for him, I can't say who she was—she said, "No,"—he then asked John Hooton if he would take it out for him, I believe Hooton took it outside; I did not see him do so—I was in the kitchen again between nine and ten o'clock the same night and the leather was gone—nothing was said in my presence about where it came from—to tell you the truth Har
rison said he had taken it from under the quartermaster's nose and he has not seen him—that same night I was at the Mitre Tavern, I saw Hooton come in; I asked him to drink with me—Harrison also came in, I can't swear whether it was the same night or not, nothing took place.

Cross-examined by MR. H. PALMER. Q. I believe you know Harrison, do you not? A. That was the first time I ever saw him—the leather was lying on the floor, it was not covered over with anything that I saw, it was not wrapped up, you could see it was leather—I was out of the kitchen two or three times during that afternoon—I had charge of the kitchen, the woman was not one of the servants—she is not here to-day—officers do not give leather work to their soldiers to do privately for them, that I am aware of—there are men in the regiment who are in the trade—there are boot makers belonging to the service who work in the shop belonging to the Government, there are also harness-makers—a great many came into the kitchen that day, non-commissioned officers, no others were allowed in Harrison is a non-commissioned officer—my commanding officer returned that evening—three men were put in the guard-room, Hooton was one and I was one, it was for being half an hour absent from the barrok-room—during my absence from the kitchen a great many people might have gone in.

JURY. Q. Where is this officers' kitchen, in the arsenal? A. No; in the West-square, going into the Artillery barracks—I was not put under arrest for having anything to do with the leather, nothing at all had been discovered about the leather then.

WILLIAM ROSS . I am a sergeant-major in the Royal Artillery—on 21st February I saw Harmon at the east-end of the West-square with a large Roll of lether under his left arm, going down to the kitchen occupied by The servent of Captain Sandman and Lientemant Plunkett—the last witness is one of their servants.
Cross-examined by MR. H. PALMER. Q. This was in broad daylight?

A. Yes; one o'clock, the soldiers go to dinner at a quarter-past one—the leather was not wrapped up in anything, Harrison belongs to the Naval Brigade, I believe; he is not in my regiment—I know nothing about his cha
racter—it is not a custom that I am aware of, for officers to employ men in the regiment to do private work for them in the leather way, I should not think so, unless they were directly employed as shoe-makers for the regiment—it has not occurred within my knowledge.

JOHN HOOTON . I am a gunner in the Royal Artillery, Harrison is a bombardier—I was in the officers' kitchen one Tuesday—Harrison asked me to carry a bundle of leather out for him—I said I would, and I did carry it for him, it was on the floor in the kitchen, wrapped up in matting—it was about five feet long I should think—I could not tell what the colour of it was, the matting entirely covered it, it felt like leather—Harrison went in front of me and I carried it about a mile from the barracks—I don't know the name of the place, we went to a beer-shop kept by Brooks—Harrison said, "Put it down there" and I put it it) to a little parlour on the right
hand side, Brooks was in another room at that time he did not see us come in,—it was about half-past six or it might have been seven when we got there—I went to the bar and had a glass of ale, Harrison did not go with me; while I was drinking at the bar I saw him and Brooks go into the parlour where the leather was put, I could see the door, it was shut—I should say they were there about ten minutes the leather was on the floor, the room was lighted by gas—they afterwards came outside, and I left the house soon after—there was a window in the parlour facing the street, the blind was drawn down—on the Thursday following I pointed out the house to a police
constable—I knew it well, I don't know the name of it.

Croat-examined by MR. H. PALMER Q. What time did you go to the officers' kitchen that day? A. I was there all day in and out—I am an officer's servant, it was my right place to be—I did not notice the leather till about half-past six in the evening, it was then in the centre of the kitchen on the floor—I have been in the service twelve years, I have deserted once, only once, there was a second charge for desertion preferred against me, and a third—I suffered punishment, there is nothing against me now—I was put under arrest on this night—I was not charged by some men in the regiment with having stolen this leather, never—the provost-sergeant spoke to me about this—he asked me if I knew anything at all about some leather that was taken out of the barracks—I had not spoken to anyone about it till then, and I should not if I had not been asked about it—I did not know what it was—I was not called out of the ranks by my colonel on parade and told that I was worse than Harrison—I saw no one at the beer-shop except Brooks, I was there about ten minutes, it was dusk then.

JOHN NEWTON . I am a sergeant in the Royal Artillery—on Thursday even
ing, 23d February, I went to Brooks's beer shop with some of the other soldiers—I remained downstairs with Crouch and Brooks—some leather had been found then—I said to Brooks, "I suppose it has cost you as much as if you had bought it lawfully"—he said, "D—d near as much"—Crouch said, "You seem to take it pretty coolly"—Brooks said, "It is no use doing any
thing else; I have got into it, and I must get out of it the best way I can."

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Where were you at the time? A. In a little parlour, what he called a shop—he had got harness hanging round it; I suppose it was a parlour at one time, and be had turned it into a shop—I wade no memorandum of the conversation—I put questions on my own account—I belong to the military police.

WILLIAM ROSS (re-examined.) It is a common thing for a soldier to carry leather from the store to the collar-maker's shop, if he is a collar-maker—persons besides collar-makers are not employed to carry it—Harrison is a collar-maker—there was nothing to excite my surprise in seeing him carry it.

JAMES WILLIAM CROUCH . I am a sergeant of police attached to the dockyards—on Thursday, 23d February, between 8 and 9, I went with the other witnesses to Brook's house in Union-street, Woolwich—the house was pointed out to me by Hooton—I did not go in at first, I stayed outside—I heard the sergeant-major say, "Here is the mark plain enough"—he was looking at the leather—I went inside—Randall and Osborn then went up
stairs, leaving Newton and I downstairs with Brooks—Newton said to Brooks, pointing to the leather, "I suppose you gave as much for this as you could buy it honestly, "or" honourably "for"—I believe the word was "lawfully"—Brooks said something, but I did not catch it—in consequence of his wanting some beer, I said, "You seem to take it very comfortably"—he said, "Well, I have got into it, and I must get out of it"—I then came away—I apprehended Harrison the next morning at the Artillery barracks—I told him I was going to take him on a charge of stealing a quantity of leather, the property of the Crown, on Tuesday last—he did not say any
thing—I told him that a man of the name of Brooks, who kept a beershop in Union-street, was in custody for receiving the leather—he said he knew nothing about the leather—Brooks appeared sober when I saw him.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Have you been long in the neigh
bourhood of Woolwich? A. Yes; I have known Brooks, I should my, thirteen or fourteen years—I believe he has borne the character of a respect
able man.

JOHN MORRIS . I am staff collar-maker at the Royal Artillery barracks at Woolwich—I have examined the leather produced; I find Government marks upon it—the value of it altogether is about 2l. 14s.—such leather as this is never condemned and sold by Government.

Cross-examined by MR. H. PALMER. Q. You know Harrison, don't you? A. Yes; he bears a good regimental character—I know a Captain Burn—I don't know that Harrison repaired a saddle for him—I know of officers giving repairing work to men in the regiment.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Have you ever attended any sales at the Arsenal? A. Never—Government use skins of this kind; this skin is not larger than the usual size; I am quite sure of that; they vary—the skins are brown when they are issued out to us, and they are mode up brown—our harness is brown.

The prisoners received good characters.—
NOT GUILTY .

482.
GEORGE BROOKS was again indicted
for unlawfully having in his custody and possession 6 pieces of leather, knowing them to be marked with the Government mark.

p.hi: gave the same evidence as in the preceding case.

div1.p: JOHN OSBORN . The evidence given by this witness was read over, and he added,—"I find the broad arrow on some of these pieces of leather."
Cross-examined. Q. Supposing a skin were damaged, would they sell it out of stock? A. If it was unserviceable; they take care not to buy damaged leather.
COURT. Q. Have you ever known leather sold? A. It is said in large
quantities in the Arsenal, but not leather like this—I have not been present at any sales.

p.hi: The evidence of John Newton, James William Crouch, and John Morris, as given in the last case, was read over to them; to which they assented.

div1.p:
WILLIAM M'OUBRAY . I am storeholder in the Royal Arsenal—I have charge of the condemned stores; I have the superintending of the sales of all of then—I have seen the leather produced here to-day; this large piece is seat-leather, to cover cloaks, and for other purposes—leather of this kind is never sold; it is new serviceable leather, unconverted—this hide is Govern
ment leather blacked; that is also new, serviceable leather—this is some more of the same not coloured—I have seen it all—I find the broad arrow on some of it, and the War Department mark.

Cross-examined. Q. What stores pass through your hands? A. Leather and blankets, chiefly the stores from foreign stations—blankets are not always torn in four before they are sold—those that I sell are chiefly horse
blankets, and I have sold the others as horse-blankets—if a skin of leather became damaged, it would be made convertible for the repairs of the De
partment work—sales take place once a quarter; up to two years back we used to have them more frequently—the last sale I had was on 12th Decem
ber—I have a foreman to assist me, but under my superintendence—I see everything as it is laid out.
MR. POLAND. Q. Do you find that this leather is damaged, so that it could not be use? A. No; it is fit for use.

GUILTY .—
Confined Twelve Months.

483.
THOMAS COOK (20), and
CHARLES WALTERS (20)
, Felo
niously cutting and wounding
Richard Henry Dennis, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

RICHARD HENRY DENNIS . I am a sawyer, and live at Princes road, Plum
stead—on Monday evening, 20th March, I was in the Royal Oak, Plumstead, with my wife, my two daughters, and my little son—I went out at the back, and the two prisoners followed my son into the room and insulted my daugh
ters—Cook pulled them about, and tried to kiss them—Walters did nothing to my daughters; he tried to get Cook out—they were got out with the landlord's assistance—Cook then went to the bar, and accused my daughter of taking a watch—they were got out of the house twice, and about a quarter of an hour after that we left—I had the best part of a quart of ale in my hand, which was for supper—some one, I cannot say who, knocked me down, and then Cook knocked me down a second time—I got up, and was going up the road; Walters then turned round, knocked me down, knelt on me, and Cook stabbed me with a knife on the top of my head—I saw the blade shine—my little daughter came up and pushed them off—I got up, and was knocked down again by Walters—my son came up, and they ran away—with the second blow the knife closed—I am very weak still, and not able to work—I was also struck with the knife when it was half shut.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you had some drink? A. A little—I was not more excited with drink than I am now; I had only had three pints and a half in the day—I had three parts of a quart in my hand, but that was spilt—I do not think I struck with the pot, but I might have, without being aware of it.
Cook., I was asked to come into the parlour, and I sat between your wife and daughter—in a few miuutes I lost my watch—after that there was

some disturbance, and I went outside and struck some one on the head with A quar pot—I can't say who it was-you afterwards struck me on the Head with something—I put up my hand, and you nearly cut the top of my finger off with a knife, which you had in your hand. Witness. I had no knife in my hand, but here is a wound on my finger from your knife—I may have kicked you when I was lying down, after I was knocked down—your finger was cut when your knife closed on your hand, when you stabbed me.

JURY. Q. Are these young men your daughters' acquaintance? A. I do not think so; they have just come home from service, and I do not think they ever met the prisoners before—I have not seen the prisoners above six times—they have never been to my house, but have been past it.
MR. DALEY. Q. Had your wife or daughters been in the public-house before you came? A. They were there when I arrived, at twenty minutes to 7.

EDWARD DAY . I keep the Royal Oak—I was called to the bar by my daughter, in consequence of disgusting and obscene language by the prisoners, and found Cook pulling one of the young women about, and trying to kiss her—her father was rebuking him—he became very excitable towards the father, who I believe struck him—I slipped in between and told Cook he ought to be ashamed of himself for striking a man old enough to be his father—he became more violent, and I asked Walters to try to get him out—he made two attempts, but was unsuccessful—one of them, when he was got outside, jumped on the counter, and swore be would kill me.
Cook. I never jumped on the counter. Witness. Ton did, and broke the glass; I bolted the door, and you broke it open and made a most foul oath that you would kill me—I know nothing about your watch.

MARY ANN DENNIS . I am the prosecutor's daughter—I was with him on 20th March, and the prisoner followed my brother in out of the tap-room, and Cook took hold of me and kissed me; their discourse was not fit for any female to mention, and my father said he would not have it, and would not have us pulled about like that—Walters tried to get him out; he took him round the waist and said, "We have been mates all our life time, why should not we be mates now?"—Cook had a watch with a silver Albert to it—he put it in his left trouser's pocket, and went out of the room directly—he came in again, and said that he had lost his watch—my mother said to Mr. Day, "You ought to have a search as we have not been out of the room"—that was before he kissed me, and, before my father came—the landlord induced them to go, and I followed my father out—he had a quart-pot in his hand with some ale in it, which he was carrying home; directly he got outside the house he was knocked down; I cannot say who by—he got up again, and I saw the prisoners run off—I did not drink with either of them—I never saw them before.

Cross-examined, Q. Was there a good deal of quarrelling after you got outside? A. Yes; I did not throw any broken earthenware, nor was any thrown—I stopped and picked up the quart pot, and some women pushed me down directly.
Cook. Q. Did not you drink with met? A. No; nor did I put it to my month—I did not draw my chair close to you, and throw my clothes over your legs; that was my sister Martha.

EMILY DENNIS . I was not at the beer-shop, but I saw the prisoners going along near our door, and my father after them—after they got round the corner, Cook began to knock my father about and got a knife,

and Walters laid his knees on my father while Cook struck him with the knife—I pulled Walters off my father; he pushed me, and called out for my brother—after that, one of the prisoners dashed my father up against the fence, and then they ran up the hill.

Cross-examined. Q. Did your father go by the door? A. Yes; he did not come in—he went straight on the other side of the way, and these two men were on first—my father had nothing in his hand then; no quart
pot and no poker—I threw a bit of china when I saw him on my father—they both threw my father down, and Walters held him down with his knees.
Cook. Q. Was not I by myself? Q. No; Walters was with you; my brother and my father were not on top of you.

RICHARD DENNIS . I am the prosecutor's son—on 20th March, he and my mother were drinking in the public-house—I went into the tap-room and asked Walters, who was there, to drink, which he did—I went to my father and mother, and went back—the prisoners came in, and I asked Walters whether he would come into the parlour, and sit with me—soon afterwards Cook insulted my sisters, and when I went back he said, "Are they your sisters?"—I said, "Yes, what is the matter?"—he said that he had lost his watch—Miss Day ordered him out of the parlour, and they went out—my father went out, and I found him lying down, and picked him up—when we got to Rutland-place, I saw my father knocked down again by Walters; he was cut, and bled very much—I took him home; Cook did nothing to my father; he was three or four yards away from him; the prisoners ran away.

Cross-examined. Q. Did not you see Walters trying to get Coot out of the public-house several times? A. Yes, he took him round the waist; I did not see that Walters was bleeding, but there was a bason of blood and water when I went into their house to give them in charge—they both live in one house.
Cook. Q. Did I ask you to drink? A. You asked Walters; you were excited with drink.

EDWARD MARSH (Policeman, R 311). I took the prisoners; I found this knife (produced), on Cook—it has stains of blood on it; Richard Dennis said that Cook had stabbed his father; Cook said, "Serve the old b——right"—Walters said, "You do not mean to put this on me, do you."
Cook. The stain on my knife was from my handkerchief, which I had had on my head; I carry them together.

DUNCAN LEWIS . I am a medical practitioner; I was called in, and found Dennis partially bent double, as if from exhaustion, and literally deluged with external blood—the temporal artery was cut through; it would have cost him his life if it had not been cut through, as that caused it to contract—I considered him in danger; he was pulseless; I found several scratches on his head, and an incised wound on the summit; also, a deep incised wound measuring two inches from the margin of the ear to the angle of the jaw, so clear and deep that if I had not required to cut it, to take up the temporal artery, I could not have made a clearer incision—there appeared to be a degree of malignancy in the cut, for it had actually cut through a portion of the cartroied gland; such a knife as this would produce the wound.
Cross-examined. Q. Is it your opinion that the prosecutor had been drinking? A. I cannot tell; the copious haemorrage must have a tendency to
sober even a drunken man—he answered every question I put to him in a rational manner, but seemed much excited.

ELIZA. MILLS . I am Cook's landlady—I bathed his head when he came in; it was cut very much, and streaming with blood, and his finger was cut very badly—I cannot say whether his head was cut with a knife, or what, but as fast as I bathed ii the blood oozed out again—he also had a blow oil the face.
Cook. I am sure it was done with a knife, because it out half through my finger as well.

COURT. Q. Did you observe the cut on his finger? A. Yes; it was very much swollen indeed, and cut too—whatever he touched he marked with blood—he knocked at the door and I let him in—the son, Richard, then rushed at the door—I put my hand out to prevent his coming in, and he pushed roe with great violence against the wall and rushed into the kitchen—the prisoners are very quiet respectable young men—they never keep late hours, or do anything I could complain off—they are plasterers.

COOK.—
GUILTY of unlawfully wounding. Recommended to mercy by the Jury, it being a tort of drunken quarrel.
Confined Six Months.

WALTERS.—
NOT GUILTY .

484.
JAMES JONES (24)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
John Currie; he was also charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with the like offence.

THOMAS DOWSEY . I am an engine-driver, in the employment of the South Eastern Railway Company—on Friday, 16th December, I was the driver of a ballast-train from Dartford, consisting of an engine and tender, twenty-two trucks, filled with gravel, and two break-carriages, one in front of the train and the other in the rear—it started about five minutes past 3 in the after
noon—it was an ordinary engine—I had no exact time to keep at the stations down the line, but had to work in between the other trains, and, if necessary, at some of the stations to go on to the sidings, so as to get out of the way of the other trains—eight of the trucks were unloaded at Abbey-wood—we took nine fresh trucks on between Dartford and Erith, before talking the others off—we got to Charlton Station about 4 o'clock, and were stopped there by a signal, and detained about a quarter of an hour—the ballast guard and the signal man at the station gave me the signal to start—a man named Lancaster was the guard of the train; I recieved my orders from him, and he received the order from the signal man—I started and went into the tunnel—at that time I had twenty-three loaded trucks—seven or eight plate-layers were riding in the break-carriage at the end of the train—John Currie was one of them—the tunnel is nearly a mile long; and is on an incline—we went about three parts of the way through—the wheels slipped pretty well all through the tunnel—the greasy state of the rails was the only cause of that—I signalled to have the breaks put on, to prevent the train from slipping back—we had put some sand on the rails to try to get along, but notwithstanding that the train stopped quite still, and we were not able to get along, though the engine was powerful enough—Lancaster then got down, but he had no time to get to the rear of the train before I felt a shock—we were then on the curve—I knew that something had come into us behind, but could not tell what it was—after that some one divided the train, and we went on with twelve of the trucks to Black heath for assist
ance

to return with the engine and bring the remainder out—I returned with the engine with Assistance into the tunnel, and found that a passenger train had run into us behind, smashing up several trucks at the end of the train, and killing five of the men on the spot—we were in the tunnel, I sup
pose, from five to seven minutes before the collision—it was about thirteen minutes from the time of leaving Charlton Station till the collision—the train had just come to a stand-still before the collision—I have stuck in the tunnel once before that, when I have been in charge of a smaller ballast train, and reported that to the authorities—I was not in the habit of un
uncoupling the train in the tunnel and bringing part out—I cannot say whether the tail lights were on when I entered the tunnel as I did not go behind to see.

Cross-examined. Q. Is there an express train which ought to leave Dart
ford at 3.15? A. No; I do not know what time it leaves—the train left Maidstone about half-past 2, or twenty minutes to 3—when I got to Charlton I should have gone straight through without stopping, but for the signal against me—the weight of the train might be 250 tons, I do not know—I heard MR. Card well, the engineer, give his evidence—when so heavy a train as that stopped it is difficult to start afresh—there is an incline and a curve in the middle of the tunnel—I had quite power enough to drive the train; if there had been half the number of carriages the wheels might have slipped all the same—the engine would be more likely to have gone through with half the number of trucks—it would carry ten trucks through; in fact, I divided the train, and then found myself able to go through—when we had got 200 yards or so into the tunnel the slipping commenced, and the guard got down—we were then going almost at a walking pace, it was just previous to stopping still—my fireman got down also—I did not see him kick ballast on the line to make it less slippery—I felt the jar on the engine as if another engine had come into us in front—when one engine backer to another there is sometimes a bit of a jerk—it was not at all a violent shock; the guard asked me what I came back for; I said I had not come back—there was a great deal of steam and noise in the tunnel—when I came out of the tunnel with half the train, Jones, the signalman, was at the end of the platform by the door of his box—the mouth of the tunnel is not very far from the Black
heath Station; I afterwards saw Mr. Chapman, the station-master—the signal-man was about 200 yards from the mouth of the tunnel, I do not know exactly—when I got to the Blackheath Station I passed along to a siding, and then went back with the engine, having left half the ballast train in the tunnel—I held my arm up to the signal-man, and told him to hold hard—I do not know whether he understood it—Lancaster was in charge of the train; we have no fixed time to run the ballast trains—they are not in the time service at all; it has occurred before in my own case, that ballast
trains have had to divide, but I cannot speak of others; I have since heard of one or two trains sticking in the same place.

COURT. Q. Is the slipping in consequence of frost or not? A. From the greasy state of the rails the engine-wheels do not adhere, as it is a very wet tunnel, and such a great quantity of steam goes through which falls on the rails, and there is always a greasiness; if it had not been for the greasy state of the rails the engine was abundantly powerful to draw the train, and more than that, we are more liable to stopping in the winter season.

DAVID TUCKER . I am signalman at the Angerstein station, which is about half a mile from Charlton station, before you enter the tunnel—the tunnel is a few yards under a mile; and about half a mile beyond it is the Black-heath

tunnel—messages are sent from Angerstein station to Charlton through the junction, and the reverse—they are telegraphed to me—on the day this matter happened I received a signal from Charlton at 4.14 for the ballast train, which I Bent on to Blackheath at once—I received an answer, in con
sequence of which I passed the ballast train, and it came through my junc
tion about 4.20—the moment it passed I telegraphed to Charlton, "Train leaving, "and sent the same signal to Blackheath at 4.14—that was the notice to the Blackheath people that the train was coming up—it entered the tunnel and I saw no more of it—at 4.32 I received a message, "Line clear"—my entries are in a book, but I have not got it here—when I tele
graphed at 4.14 that the train was coming up, I got no answer till 4.32—they ought to answer, not to telegraph to me, but only to turn the needle over to "Train on line"—they did not send that message—they should merely turn the needle over with one beat on the gong, which affects my needle also—at 4.32 I received a message from Blackheath, "Line clear"—that would indicate to me that the train I had sent on bad passed the Black
heath station—they cannot telegraph from Charlton station on the signal instrument without sending it through me, but they can on the speaking instrument—when I got the message at 4.32 which indicated that the ballast train had gone on past Blackheath, I passed the message on to Charlton station—as soon as I had done that, there were two beats for a passenger train starting from Charlton—I passed that on to Blackheath, and it was answered by the needle which turned over to "Train on line"—the passenger train came through my junction at 4.35 or 36, and entered the tunnel—the tail lamps were on—I heard of the accident about a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes after that, when the guard came out of the tunnel—the ballast train had passed me sufficiently long to have passed the Blackheath station before I received the signal, "Line clear"—if it had not stuck fast in the tunnel, it would have passed out in sufficient time—two beats on the bell are either for a passenger train, or anything going to London Bridge—we give two or three beats as a distinction between a train from Bricklayers' Arms and one from London Bridge—three beats means a train from Bricklayers' Arms—the line divides for Bricklayers' Arms at New Cross, which is some way beyond Blackheath—the luggage trains are put on a list and sent to me, but not all the ballast trains—by the rules, a telegram ought to be sent that a ballast train has passed—there is an order to the effect that a message should be sent before starting to each station—I did not receive any message with reference to that ballast train, or any other notice of it, only the signal from Charlton—as far as I know, the only notice sent on to the prisoner was my signal to him—a coal train up left the Angerstein junction at 3.59—there were two down trains shortly after the ballast train passed me—about thirty passenger trains pass my junction, up and down, in a day—the average is about forty with engines and goods' trains; and the same would pass Blackheath—judging from whit I now know, that train must have passed while the ballast train was in the tunnel.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you any speaking instrument at the Anger
stein station? A. Yes—that would put me in communication with Charlton and also with Blackheath station—a train going to the Bricklayers' Arms is signaled by three beats, whether it is a goods' or a passenger train—the signalman would not know what it was; lie would only know that it was a' train to Bricklayers' Arms—the traffic was heavy on that afternoon, more so than in any time in the day; there were more trains in the afternoon—the train which preceded the ballast train from Charlton was a coal train,

which started from Angerstein wharf for the Bricklayers' Arms—that was signaled by me by three beats on the instrument—I am not aware that it was delayed some little time at Blackheath station—I received the telegram at 4.12, and immediately gave three beats again—there were two signals in succession of three beats—when I received the answer to the second three beats, "Line clear, "I immediately telegraphed to Charlton, and the train started from Charlton—the ballast train was a very heavy one—the coal train wad mentioned in the time service-book, therefore the signalman at the Blackheath station would be prepared for it—the ballast train was not in the time service, and therefore it ought to be telegraphed to me from the Charlton station by a message through the speaking instrument, or from the station below, where they start the message from.

COURT. Q. Did you receive from Charlton a signal, "Passenger train started?" A. Yes, at 4.32—I sent that on to Blackheath, and received a signal from Blackheath, which turned the needle over to "Train on line"—the passenger train then came on—I did signal back to Charlton, "Train on line"—that means I have received your message.

GEORGE CLAYTON . I am station master at Charlton—I was on duty there when this accident happened—the ballast train was detained some time, and after it had left a passenger train from Maidstone came into the, station—it ought not to have stopped there, but it did so because the signals were at danger—it arrived at 4.20, and was detained about twelve minutes—the passengers were very impatient, and I telegraphed to Blackheath, to the station-master, by words, "Train waiting"—that is a customary thing when a train is kept a long while—I got no answer, no further than in the signal-box the "All clear" signal was given at 4. 32, which was almost immediately before I could leave the office—that would be from Tucker's place—the train then left—that would be about 4.33 1/2.

Cross-examined. Q. My friend asked you whether you telegraphed to the station-master at Blackheath; are you aware that the telegraph station there is in charge of a boy? Q. Yes—important messages like that are entrusted to his care—the ballast train had not been signaled to me through the speaking instrument, nor had I telegraphed it on by message to Blackheath; it was not my place to do so—the passengers in the express were impatient, and I gave a reminder—a ballast train leaving Charlton arrives at Black
heath sometimes in seven, eight, or ten minutes, but eight minutes had elapsed on that occasion—I telegraphed, "Train waiting"—we make it as short and explicit as we can—I could have telegraphed, "Has ballast train passed?"—that would have given some notice to the signalman of a ballast train—I called his attention very distinctly to the second three beats—I did not give him notice of that special ballast train, which I might have done—when I said, "Train waiting" the signal was against me—I have sent many such messages before and since, but I do not know what man I sent them to—I telegraph to the station.
MR. METCALFE. Q. Would you want the "line dear" signal just the same? Q. Yes.

CHARLES EDWARD BARTHOLOMEW . I am assistant booking-clerk at Black
heath station, and work the speaking-telegraph as well—on the Friday this matter happened, I received a telegram at 4.31 from Charlton station, "Train waiting"—I told the outside porter, Jupp, to go and tell the signal
man, Jones, at the signal-box—I sent no reply; I left it to be done through the regular signals—it was merely a verbal message by Jupp.
Cross-examined. Q. How long have you been in charge of that telegraph

office? A. About eight months—I have never before received such a mes
sage from Charlton station as "Train waiting"—when I receive a message in that way through the speaking instrument it is my duty to write it down—I did not do so on that occasion—no communication ought to be made to the signalman except in writing with reference to any message from the speaking instrument.
COURT. Q. How old are you? A. Turned fourteen—this was my first employment on a railway.

JESSE RUPP . I am a porter at Blackheath station—on the Friday after
noon that that accident happened, Bartholomew told me to go to the prisoner at the signal-box and say that there was a train waiting at Charlton—I went to the prisoner's box door and told him so—he said, "Very well, I thought I heard three beats some little time ago"—he said nothing more—I left the box and came away—I did not see him use the instrument.

Cross-examined. Q. Was he perfectly sober? A. Yes; I have never seen him the worse for liquor—when he said that he heard three beats, I said that I did not know anything about it—I am not paid by the company—I am not in their employ—I only take parcels.

EDWARD DUNCAN CHAPMAN . I am station-master at Blackheath—I have been nearly eighteen years in the company's employ, and am perfectly acquainted with the working of the line—it is a rule that when a train is started a message should be sent from the starting station—in starting from Dart ford the station-master would send a message along the line which would be immediately conveyed to the signalman, and that train would be added to their list of expected trains, which was not done in this instance, and the ballast train became entirely dependant on signals from station to station—the prisoner had been porter for two years and four months—he had been working the signals altogether for about eight or nine days—he had been well taught before he was put into the signal box—every person in the com
pany's employ is required to make himself acquainted with the rules—he had taken the duty of assistant signalman to help the day man when he went to dinner, and from 6 to 8 in the evening on several occasions when I had given one of the staff a holiday—he was my reserve man, and was par
ticularly steady and sober, and one of the best men I ever had under my charge—his hours were from 7 in the morning to 6 in the evening with one hour for dinner—he had no other duties but signaling—this message which was sent from Charlton station by the porter was decidedly irregular; it should have been copied in writing and sent to the signalman so as to impress it more on his mind—they are not justified in attending to merely verbal messages, and if the prisoner had attended to this message he would have done wrong—the regulations are strict you must have a written message to act upon—I cannot understand how the man made a mistake—orders to the signalman may be given verbally by me but by no one else except the head porter when he is acting as my deputy—trains have been stopped in the tunnel and divided before—that arises from the wet dripping through and making the rails greasy and very often from atmospheric causes—it is often not so bad as at other times—it has happened many times since I have been at Blackheath—it has always been reported, and all precautions are supposed to be taken and rules are laid down which were considered sufficient—not taking so many trucks would decidedly be the remedy for it.

COURT. Q. If it was signaled down the line that it was slippery, need they put so many trucks on? A. Well, I do not know it is not a very pleasant place to go into—we do not go often to look at the state of the rails—the plate-layers walk through every day, and if anything is wrong they would
report it—if life was in danger no exertions would be wanting on my part, but it is not the place of the traffic department to examine the tunnel—my duty is at the station.

MR. METCALFE. Q. Were there two passenger trains which passed just at that time? A. Yes; they were signaled in the ordinary way—I have not got the prisoner's book—the law department have had the charge of it since the accident—I went to the prisoner's box about the time of the col
lision, as I understood he wanted to speak to me—he said, "I understand the ballast train has divided in the tunnel"—I saw he was agitated, and he said, "I am afraid I have given the clear signal"—I immediately telegraphed to Charlton station, but at that time the collision had taken place.

Cross-examined. Q. How old is the prisoner? A. Twenty-four—I have given him a very good character, and I believe him to be anxiously careful to do his duty—he had not received signal-man's wages, as his first week had not elapsed—he would be entitled to them—his wages as a porter were 16s. a week—he has married since he has been at Blackheath-station—his wages as a signal-man would be one guinea—I treat this entirely as a mistake; I cannot account for it—the signal-man in charge has four columns to make entries in for each train between its being received and having passed the station—I do not know whether he would have to make 150 entries in three
quarters of an hour—in addition to the four entries to each signal, he has to hold out a flag for each train that passes, and to put up the semaphore arms—there were trains at 3.30 and 3.50 from Charing-cross; 4.5 and 4.20—the 4.30 would not arrive till after the collision—only one empty train went previous to the coal train.

EDWARD WINGFIELD . I am a time-keeper in the service of the South
eastern Company—I knew John Cumming, who was injured in the accident—he died in the Royal Marine hospital at Woolwich from the injuries he received.

The prisoners statement before the Magistrate:—"I entered the company's service two years last August as porter, which situation I held up to a week previous to the accident, when I was placed in the signal-box to do duty for the signal-man who was ill. I don't believe I had done more than twenty duties in the signal-box, that is to say, when there was any signalling to do, before I took charge of it, so that my previous experience was but little. However, when I took the duty I hoped I should have been able to have performed it satisfactorily. My duties were to attend in the signal-box from 7 in the morning until 6 in the evening, with the exception of the hour allowed for dinner. After coming out of the box at 6, I had to wait the arrival and to attend the 6.17 down train. Whilst in the box I had to receive and give telegraphic signals to and from Lewisham-station, and to and from Angerstein-junction. I had beside to enter signals in five different places for each train in the signal-book in addition. I had for each train or engine to attend to the semaphore and distinct signal, and upon each train passing to show my flag or hand-signal that all was right. I will now state briefly the circumstances connected with the lamentable acci
dent so far as I am able, and the traffic that passed through the station within three-quarters of an hour of it. The following trains passed through the Blackheath-station:—Down from London 3.30, 3.50 (expressed), 4.5, 420 (expressed). Due at Blackheath, 3 51, 4.7, 4.25, 431. The next down train, the 4.30, due at 4.47, was fortunately stopped at Blackheath. Up from Woolwich, 3 30. Due at Blackheath 3.44. Angerstein coal-train, 4.5. Blackheath empties'-train, 4.10. Ballast-train, signalled up at 413.

I believe I had in addition the block-signal, prior to the coal-train from An
gerstein-junction, but this I am not quite sure without seeing the train-service
book. I had been in the practice, prior to the day, to send the coal
train off first from our Blackheath-station, but I was ordered by the head
porter to keep the coal-train, and send the empties off first, which was the cause of the train being kept at Charlton. During this time the traffic was very great, and I felt it was as much as I could do to attend to it properly. After the coal-train was gone, and I had given the 'line clear' to Anger
stein-junction, I had the 4.5 express-signal down, and after passing that on to Angeratein-junction, and receiving 'line clear,' I had the 420 express-signal down. Somebody at this time came running out of the Telegraph-office telling me there was a train waiting at Charlton; this message, together with the heavy traffic then taking place, caused me to get confused, and I gave the signal 'line clear.' I was so confused that I did not know what I was about; so much so that I was very much surprised to find it was the outside porter who had brought me the telegraph message out—I could have sworn it was one of the telegraph boys. After the 4.20 down express had passed our station, I thought I had done something wrong as regards the signalling. I immediately sent for Mr. Chapman, the station-master, to tell him of what I had done. I did not at that moment know of the accident He came down on the platform from his house, after half of the ballast-train had passed the station; he came to me, and I think I told him what had taken place as to my signalling. All would have gone well if I had been left alone, and not have received the telegraph message, which seemed wholly to confuse me. I took my eyes off the signals for a moment, and believed at the time I gave the signal 'line clear' that it was the right thing for me to do."
NOT GUILTY .

485.
JAMES JONES was again indicted
for Feloniously killing and slaying
William Wade,
William Jones,
Henry Petchley,
Robert Morris, and
William Seeley; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

486.
JANE MARVIN (45)
,
PLEADED GUILTY to Feloniously having in her possession a mould for coining.—
Five Years' Penal Servitude; and

487.
MARTHA BRITAIN (30)
, to Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.—
Confined Nine Months.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

488.
WILLIAM GEORGE THOMPSON (20)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
George France, and stealing therein 1 opera-glass, 1 coat, and 1 shirt, his property.

GEORGE FRANCE . I live at Ceylon-street, Battersea, with my father, who is a civil engineer—I have seen the prisoner in the Wandsworth-road—he called about a week before 30th March, and said that he could draw very well—I have seen him five or six times—the family went to bed on 30th March about 10 o'clock—I went over the house, and saw it safe—I came down between 6.30 and 7 next morning, and found the kitchen-window open

—I missed a pair of boots and opera-glass, a cloak, and a shirt, worth about 5l. 10s.—this is the opera-glass (produced),—here is a little scratch on it where I marked it for the sight; I know it by that.

ARTHUR SMITHERS . I am assistant to Mr. Clark, pawnbroker, of High-street, Clapham—this opera-glass was pledged there on 31st March by the prisoner in the name of William Thomas, Park-road—I afterwards picked him out from a number of others.

JOHN SAPPHILL (Policeman, V 342.) On 31st March I examined the prosecutor's premises, and found marks on the kitchen-window as if a knife had been put between the sashes to push the catch back—I made inquiries, and found the opera-glass at the pawnbroker's—I then went, in consequence of information, to 15, Finsbury-street, Blackfriars-road, and asked whether Mr. Thompson was in—I found the prisoner there, and charged him with the burglary—he said, "Very well"—he was placed with six or seven others at the station, and Smithers picked him out, and said, "That is the man that pledged the goods"—I said, "Go and touch him, "and he went and touched the prisoner, who made no reply—as I took him to the Police-court he that he had pawned the glasses.

Prisoner's Defence. On 31st March I met William Thomas, who I had been with on several occasions; he asked me to pawn the glasses for him, which I did for 6s., and he gave me 1s. 11d. I know nothing of the rob
bery.
GUILTY . He was further charged with a previous conviction at Dartford, in October, 1864, to which he

PLEADED GUILTY. **—
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

489.
CHARLES JONES (25)
, Robbery on
William Todd, and stealing from his person 1 watch, his property.

WILLIAM TODD . I am an engineer, of 3, Albert-place, Hercules-build
ings—on the night of 9th April, about 9 o'clock, the prisoner came up to me in the Brixton-road, and said, "I will see you home"—I was a little elevated, but quite sensible, and capable of taking care of myself—I had had three half-pints of porter in five hours—I said, "You are a stranger to me, I want none of your company"—he kept pressing himself upon me, and when I got up to Wallcot-square he put his arm through mine, and threw me into the middle of the highway with great violence—I fell on my left side, bruised my eye by the fall, and became insensible—while I was lying on my side he wrenched my watch, which was in my right-hand waistcoat-pocket, from my gold guard chain, and ran away—he was shortly afterwards brought back by a policeman—this is my watch (produced), and this is the guard.

Prisoner. Q. You were lying in the middle of the road flat on your face when I picked you up? A. It is false; I was walking steadily down the road when you accosted me—I did not ask you to take care of my watch, nor did I stumble and break it off the guard.

HENRY TAYLOR . I live at 12, Richmond-street, Kennington-road—I was standing at the corner of Walcot-place, and saw Todd on the ground, and the prisoner lying over him—the prisoner left him, and Todd called out, "My watch"—the prisoner ran by me towards Walcot-square, I followed close to his heels—he ran by the "Ship "into the Kennington-road again, and then he walked and smoked a pipe—I have no doubt he is the man—I faced him before he was given in custody—I then left him, went
back to the prosecutor, and found him still on the ground; he appeared hurt—I then went back with Mr. Hulls.

HULLS. I am a coppersmith, of 20, Wallcot-square—I was going home, and saw the prisoner and Todd on the ground together—I am posi
tive the prisoner is the man; he ran away—I picked Todd up, and then followed him, and gave him into custody.

JOHN GALLIER (Policeman, L 199.) Taylor spoke to me, in consequence of which I overtook the prisoner on Kennington-green, and asked Taylor, in his presence, if he was the man who took the watch from the man who was knocked down in Wallcot-square—he said, "Yes"—I put my hand on the prisoner, and asked him for the watch, or to tell me what he had done with it—he said, "It is all right"—I said, "All right will not do for me, and said that he must tell me where it was, or give it to me"—he put his hand in his waistcoat-pocket, and gave me this watch—he was charged at the station, and said that he never intended to keep it, but the man asked him to take care of it, and he could not get it off, so was obliged to break the chain—I asked him if be knew Mr. Todd; he said, "No"—I asked him if he knew where he lived; he said, "At 3, Albert-place, Hercules-buildings, and that he was going to return the watch to him to-morrow."

Prisoner. Q. Did you go to my employer? A. I did, and found that you bore a very good character, but you had only been employed there a week; I also found that you had been employed by Mr. Oartwright, in the New Cut, who also gave you a good character for four or five months.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate:—"I did not strike him at all, he was drunk and incapable; when I first saw him he was lying in the centre of the road, near Brixton Church; I saw him as far as the "Horns, "he said I was a good sort of fellow, and he would reward me with a glass of ale; I said I did not want any; he was reeling along the road. When we got to Kennington-road he wanted me to leave him, but I said I would see him further; he said, "Take care of my watch, I live at 3, Hercules-buildings;" he tried to give me the watch, but we both fell together, and then it was broken from the chain; I put it into my pocket, intending to return it the next day.

GUILTY .—
Confined Nine Months. Before Mr. Recorder.

490.
THOMAS STANTON (17)
, Stealing a purse and 10s., the property of
Mary Westbrook, from her person.

MARY WESTBROOK . I am a widow, living at No. 20, Vine-terrace, Lam
beth—on Saturday night, 1st April, about half-past 9, I was in the Waterloo-road with a basket full of potatoes, and some grocery, on my arm—the prisoner came to my side, and made an attempt to snatch a purse out of my left hand which was underneath the basket—he gave a second pull, and I saw his face distinctly—there was no lamp-post there; there was light enough to enable me to see his features—he then ran up Granville-street—there was a 5s. piece and 3s. in my purse—he took the purse and the money—I took my things home, and then went down Tower-street, and gave information to the police—I described the man—I saw him again on Monday morning, at Tower-street station, amongst several more, and I picked him out—I said, "I feel quite sure he is the man, if there were 100 people there"—I feel quite sure of him now.
Cross-examined. Q. What you said was "If there was a hundred people

you could not see one so much like him? "A. I said if there was a hundred there I could pick him out—I said I could not see one so much like him—he came up to me on the left side—my purse was in my left hand; my arm was through the handle of my basket—my finger was round the elastic of my purse or he would have got it the first time—there were several people at the station—I did not notice any but that man—the policeman said, "Walk behind me and point out the man, "and when I came to the prisoner I said, "I believe that is the man"—the policeman said, "You must not think, do you feel sure, "and I said "Yes."
MR. WOOD Q. Did you point him out yourself? A. Yes—I did not trouble myself about the others.

WILLIAM MULLINS (Policeman, L 126.) I was present when the prose
cutrix came to the station—I saw her pick out the prisoner from amongst nine or ten others—she pointed him out herself—the prisoner was the last—they were all in a row—when she came to him she said, "I believe he is the man"—I said, "You must not think; do you feel sure, "and she said, "I do, and if you were to place a thousand more before me, I could not see one like him"—I have known the prisoner a long time in the neighbourhood—he lives about a quarter of a mile from the station—I have been on the boat some time.

Cross-examined. Q. He was not apprehended on this charge at all? A. No—there is a man very similar to him; a companion of his, Mears, who was in the dock just now—from the description we received we thought it was Mears—Donovan, Mears, and Stanton were apprehended on another charge—the Grand Jury have thrown out the bill against Stanton in the other case—all three men were at the station when the prosecutrix came, and some others; some older and one or two younger—there were three children, about twelve years of age, but not near them—the prosecutrix picked out Stanton from about ten others—I believe there were one or two younger than the prisoner there; they were twelve or fourteen years old.

GUILTY .—
Confined Eighteen Months. (see next cases.),

491.
CORNELIUS DONOVAN (18), and
WALTER MEARS (19)
, Robbery on
Rebecca Vickress, and stealing from her person, 1 pencil-case, 1 purse, 1 piece of paper, and 1l. 16s. her goods.

REBECCA VICKRESS . I am a widow, living at Billinghurst, in Essex—on 27th March, between 4 and half-past, I was coming out of a shop in the Westminster-road—I was not quite certain I had all the articles I had bought; I turned round to put my purse in my pocket, when a lad came up, gave me a blow in the chest, and snatched my purse away—there were three of them together—I have no means of identifying the prisoners—I was so surprised and frightened—I had between 2l. and 3l. in money, a gold pencil-case, and a bank-stock receipt for 400l. in my purse—the purse has not been seen since—I ran after the man to Mason-street—a boy named Piper said the man had run down Mason-street—I called "Stop thief! "

SAMUEL PIPER . I live at 121, Westminster-bridge Read, and am engaged by Mr. Rogers, a bootmaker—on the afternoon of 27th March, I saw, about half-past 4, the last witness in the Westminster-bridge-road—I was I standing in a doorway—I heard a cry of "Stop thief! "and saw Mears running as hard as he could run—I knew him previously by sight—he turned up Mason-street—he had something small in his hand, but I could not see what it was; his hand was closed—he turned round Mason-street,
and ran up Blythe-terrace, and I loot sight of him—I then came down Mason-street, and saw Mrs. Vickreas speaking to a constable—I then went indoors.
COURT. Q. Did Mears run as fast as he could? A. Yes; I could not catch him.

JOHN CARROLL . I live at 77, Carlisle-street—on 27th March, about half-past 4, I saw the two prisoners in the Westminster-bridge-road running away, and heard the prosecutrix crying "Stop thief!"—I had known the prisoners a long time before—I afterwards saw the lady speaking to a con
stable, and I gave him information of what I had seen—-Donovan was running I about half a yard ahead of the other, and the lady was about half a dozen yards behind them.
DONOVAN. Why didn't you give me in charge, you saw me on the Friday following. Witness. I did not know whether to give him in charge or not; there was no policeman near at the time.
MR. WOOD. Q. Have you any doubt whatever about these being the two men the lady was following? A. Oh, no; I am sure they are right.
ROBERT HARDINGHAM (Policeman, L 163.) I took the twoprisoners into custody on 2d April—I took Mears first on 28th March; the last witness had not seen the prisoners then.
JOHN WINTER (Policeman, L 88). I saw the prisoners together on the Saturday night previous to the robbery, about 12 as near as possible—I have also seen them together on several other occasions.

Mean' Defence. Is it possible for a man to go and steal a woman's purse at that time of the day, and run that distance without being stopped. I am innocent of this. I have been in trouble before, and if there is anything done of this kind the police take me on suspicion, whether innocent or not.
GUILTY .

492.
CORNELIUS DONOVAN and
WALTER MEARS were again indicted for
a robbery, with violence, on
Charles Riches, and stealing from him 7s. his money.

CHARLES RICHES . I live at 10, Stone-street, Borough-market, and am a fitter—on Sunday morning. 2d April, I was passing along Lower Marsh, and I was knocked down by the prisoners, and kicked several times while on the ground—there was a third man whom I cannot speak to—as I was rising from the ground I was robbed of two half-crowns and a 2s. piece, by Donovan—I said to him, "You scoundrel, you are not contented with knocking me about and kicking me, but you have robbed me"—he said be had not—he passed the money to Mears and made off, down a bye-street—a crowd came up, and the prisoners ran away—I went to the police-station, and gave a description of them, a few minutes after, and on the evening of the same day I was sent for to the station—I then identified the two prisoners from seven others—I was sober.

HERBERT HARDINGHAM (Policeman, L 163.) On the evening of the Saturday previous to this robbery, about a quarter to 9, I saw the prisoners together at the Spanish Patriot—I took them into custody at 10 o'clock the next evening—they were together then—I charged them with assaulting and robbing Mr. Riches in the Lower-marsh, about half-past 12 the same evening—Mears said that whenever there was anything occurred, I was always down upon him—I was at the station when the prosecutor came there—there were five others put with the prisoners; there was a third one taken on this charge who he not could speak to, but he spoke positively to
these two; I had taken Donovan and Stanton into custody on the Thursday night previous.

JOHN WINTER (Policeman, L 88.) On the evening of the Saturday previous to this robbery, I saw Donovan, Mears, and Stanton by a public-house in the Lower Marsh, about 12 o'clock—the two prisoners crossed over the road and parted from Stanton, and I followed them along the Westminster
on the road.

THOMAS PHELAN (Policeman, L 170.) I took Donovan—I told him the charge—he said he was not with Mears that night—he was along with Stanton—I took him on the Sunday, and he said he had not been with him Saturday night.

HENRY POWELL . I am a salesman, and live at 11, Lambeth-square—I have known the two prisoners by sight—on this Sunday morning I was in the Lower Marsh, about half-past 12, and saw a crowd of persons—I went up and saw two men lifting the prosecutor from the ground—his face was much cut; I saw one of the men's hands in his pocket, and then he passed something to a third person, and ran down the next street—they all three ran away—I had a slight glimpse of their faces—I knew the prisoners by sight—I could not swear whether they were the men or not; I can't swear one way or the other—I believe Donovan was one of them—I have no belief about the others, one way or the other.
Donovan's Defence. I was not there; I am as innocent as a new-born babe.

DONOVAN.—
GUILTY .**—
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.

MEARS.—
GUILTY .—
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

493.
SARAH ORCHARD (alias),
DURBAT (35)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
William Hutton.

ELIZABETH HUTTON . I live at 6, Herbert's-buildings—the deceased was my father—he was a cooper, and his name was William Hutton—on the Tuesday that this happened he was in good health—he had just done a tub—he was sitting near the fire—the prisoner came in and hulloaed out, "Mrs. Hutton"—my mother was not at home—the prisoner had lent us two lasts, and she came and asked for her lasts—I got up and gave her one, and said as soon as my mother came in I would give her the other—she then made use of bad language, and said she would not go without the other—my father said, "If you use such bad language before my children I will put you out"—she said, "You, you muck; you nor your betters could not do it"—father came out of the shed where he worked, and when he was about half a yard away from the prisoner, she struck him on the right temple with the last—he bled very much, and fell into David Brown's arms—he told me to fetch a policeman; I went, and could not see one, and when I came back the prisoner was gone—my father sat by the fire, with his hand up to his forehead, and he was never sensible afterwards till he died.
Prisoner. The little girl was not there. She passed by, and called me some bad name.
Witness. I did not—my father told me to have no words with her—she dropped the last on my toe, and I said, "Mind my toe, "and that is all I said.

DAVID BROWN . I am a labourer at the London Gas works—I was present on this Tuesday in Herbert's-buildings—I saw the prisoner strike Mr. Hutton over the temple, over the right eye, with a last which was hanging on her two first fingers by a bit of string—I caught Hutton in my arms, took him into the room and put him in a chair; he bled very much and appeared very fatigued—I do not remember the day of the month.

COURT. Q. Had she been provoked in any way before this? A. No; Mr. Hutton only told her not to use bad language, and if she did he would put her out of the room—she said he could not, he went towards her to put her out and she struck the blow.

FRANK HUGHES . My father and mother are dead—previous to this I had been living in the streets—I was in Herbert's-buildings on this day, inside the gate—I saw this woman strike the old man with a boot last, which she had in her hand by a piece of string—I am now living in Si George's-house my uncle took me there.
Prisoner. Q. Were you not on the other side of the way? A. No—I was waiting for Mrs. Hutton's son Johnny to come home—I was playing buttons.
COURT. Q. This occurred in the room did it not? A. Yes, where she struck him; I could see into the room, the door was open.

MARY HUTTON . I am the wife of the deceased—I was out when this occurred—when I came back I found him bleeding very much from the temple, he sat all the evening with his hand up to his head and continued so every day for a week after—he sot delirious and loft his senses—I fetched Mr. Wakeham's assistant nearly three weeks afterwards—Mr. Wakeham is dead, a young man saw him—my husband was thirty-eight years of age and in quite good health, he had been at hard work all day.

Prisoner's Defence. I went and asked Mr. Hutton for the last and he said "There's one, I don't know where the other is, the children bare taken it out and lost it"—I said, "It is very kind not to return things that are lent, "and I sat myself down on the bench, and said, "I shan't go without it, "before I could say anything else he caught me round the waist and chucked me out on the stones—I gave myself a twist out of his arms and gave him a push.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months. The prisoner was
also charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with the manslaughter of the said
William Hutton and
acquitted.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, MAY 8TH, 1865.

div0.p: The following Prisoners, upon whom the Judgment of the Court was respited at the time of the Trial, have since been sentenced as under:

3
Fuller, Edward... 87... Five Years' Penal Servitude.

4
Astwood, Edwin Greg.... 148... Confined Six Months.

7
Phillips, William... 383... Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

8
Ward, Henry... 383... Eight Years' Penal Servitude.

9
George Charles Beard... 385... Confined Three Days.

11
Blair, Mary... 407... Tried again, and discharged 11th of April, 1865.

18
Smithers, Thomas... 558... Five Years' Penal Servitude.

20
De Costa, John... 570... Confined One Month.
